1 Introductory Material 1 
1.1 Foreword 2 
This Technical Specification has been produced by the O-RAN Alliance. 3 
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within O-RAN and may change following formal 4 
O-RAN approval. Should the O-RAN Alliance modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by O-5 
RAN with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows:  6 
Release x.y.z 7 
where: 8 
x the first digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, 9 
etc. (the initial approved document will have x=01). 10 
y the second digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document.  11 
z the third digit included only in working versions of the document indicating incremental changes during the 12 
editing process. 13 
1.2 Scope 14 
1.2.1 General 15 
The present document defines tests that validate the conformance to the protocols defined in [2] for the Lower Layer 16 
Split Option 7.2x interface between the O-RU and the O-DU.  A guiding principle for these conformance tests is to use 17 
only standard interfaces that are defined by the specification [2] or relevant 3GPP specifications.  The construction of 18 
these tests avoids the requirement for a device to include any special interfaces used solely for the purpose of these 19 
tests. 20 
While these tests are not written to evaluate the performance of an O-DU or O-RU device, some tests require obtaining 21 
measurements and evaluating the success or failure of the device to process sample data correctly based on portion of 22 
the protocol being tested at the time.     23 
In general, unless otherwise stated, the tests cover LTE (Stand-Alone), NR Non-Stand-Alone (NSA) and NR Stand-24 
Alone (SA).  25 
In the main body of this specification (in any “chapter”) the information contained therein is normative meaning 26 
binding on any compliant system, unless explicitly described as informative (a capability described as “optional” may 27 
or may not be included in a compliant system but if it is included it must comply with the optional capability 28 
description).  Information contained in an “Annex” to this specification is always informative.  29 
1.2.2 U-Plane and C-Plane Scope 30 
This version of the Conformance Test specification defines tests which validate the conformance of an O-RU and O-31 
DU.  The tests are designed to cover a large number of optional functionalities defined in [2].  Therefore, for any given 32 
O-RU implementation, a subset of these tests may not be applicable.  It is the responsibility of the tester to understand 33 
the applicability of each test to the feature provided by a particular O-RU.    34 
1.2.3 S-Plane  35 
The  Conformance Test specification defines tests for time synchronization of the O -RU and O-DU.  The tests defined 36 
include both functional and performance tests.  Functional tests validate the ability of the O -RU and O-DU to achieve 37 
the proper synchronization management state based on a variety of PTP, and optionally SyncE input conditions.  38 
Performance tests validate the conformance of the recovered clock for the O -DU or O-RU.   39 
Concerning the scope of the S-Plane, various synchronization options have been defined in the O-RAN CUS 40 
Specification [2] for distributing synchronization to the O-RU (LLS-C1, LLS-C2, LLS-C3 and LLS-C4). Depending on 41 
the specific O-RAN deployment being considered not all of them may be relevant. When testing the S-Plane, the tester 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 7 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
shall identify which of the test cases are relevant depending on the specific deployment scenarios addressed. As a 1 
general guideline the following applies: 2 
1) Direct connection between O-DU and O-RU:  3 
• LLS-C1 is generally the main sync option to be validated.  4 
• LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to C1 5 
2) Synchronization network between O-DU and O-RU 6 
• LLS-C2 for cases where the synchronization is delivered to the O-RU via the O-DU and over the bridged 7 
network. In this topology the PRTC synchronizing the O-DU may be local or remote.  8 
• LLS-C3 for cases when the synchronization is distributed to the O-RU without involving the O-DU. In 9 
this case one or more PRTC may be remote and may also be local. 10 
• LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to LLS-C2/C3 11 
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2, a local PRTC is either embedded in or co-located with the O-DU. A remote PRTC is 12 
located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul).    13

 15 
1.2.4 Test Requirement Status 16 
The following table is a list of each test in this conformance specification and status of the test as MANDATORY or 17 
CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  Note that tests that are MANDATORY are for those functions of the DUT that by 18 
specification are required to be supported.  Optional functionality in a DUT implies that the corresponding conformance 19 
test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and is mandatory only if the DUT supports the optional functionality.  20 
The M-Plane conformance tests are applicable to both the O-RU and the O-DU.  Some of the M-Plane tests are 21 
specifically targeting the protocol conformance of the O-RU and are not necessary for conformance testing of a O-DU.  22 
Therefore, for M-Plane tests, the table below has two “Test Requirement” columns describing if the test is mandatory, 23 
conditional mandatory or optional for testing an O-RU or a O-DU.   If a test is OPTIONAL, it does not need to be 24 
included in a conformance test of the device but could be included if desired.  25

1.4 Definitions 28 
For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in 3GPP TR 21.905, “Vocabulary for 3GPP 29 
Specifications”[1]and the following apply. A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition 30 
of the same term, if any, in [1] 31 
C-Plane Control Plane: refers specifically to real-time control between O-DU and O-RU, and should not be 32 
confused with the UE’s control plane 33 
DL DownLink: data flow towards the radiating antenna 34 
eNB eNodeB (applies to LTE) <E-UTRAN NodeB / Evolved NodeB> 35 
EVM Error Vector Magnitude – see section 6.5.2 Modulation quality in 3GPP TS 38.104 36 
fm-pm Fault Management, Performance Management role 37 
gNB gNodeB (applies to NR) <Next Generation NodeB> 38 
M-Plane Management Plane: refers to non-real-time management operations between the O-DU and the O-39 
RU 40 
NETCONF Network Configuration Protocol. For details see: RFC 6241, “Network Configuration Protocol 41 
(NETCONF)”, IETF, June 2011 42 
NSA Non-Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of SgNB attached to MeNB 43 
O-CU O-RAN Central Unit – a logical node hosting PDCP, RRC, SDAP and other control functions  44

O-DU O-RAN Distributed Unit: a logical node hosting RLC/MAC/High-PHY layers based on a lower 1 
layer functional split. O-DU in addition hosts an M-Plane instance. 2 
O-RU O-RAN Radio Unit <O-RAN Radio Unit: a logical node hosting Low-PHY layer and RF 3 
processing based on a lower layer functional split. This is similar to 3GPP’s “TRP” or “RRH” but 4 
more specific in including the Low-PHY layer (FFT/iFFT, PRACH extraction).>. O-RU in 5 
addition hosts M-Plane instance. 6 
PTP Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a protocol for distributing precise time and frequency over 7 
packet networks. PTP is defined in the IEEE Standard 1588. 8 
PDCCH Physical Downlink Control Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface  9 
PBCH Physical Broadcast Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface 10 
SA Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of gNB attached to a 5G Core Network  11

SSB Synchronization Signal Block, in 5G PBCH and synchronization signal are packaged as a single 13 
block 14 
subordinate The term “subordinate” is used as a replacement for “slave” and is consistent with its use in CUS 15 
specification. When consensus emerges on how to eliminate the use of the term “slave” in the 16 
referenced standards organization, that approach will be applied to this specification  17 
sudo Super-User Do role 18 
S-Plane Synchronization Plane: Data flow for synchronization and timing information between nodes 19 
SyncE Synchronous Ethernet, is an ITU-T standard for computer networking that facilitates distribution 20 
of clock signals over the Ethernet physical layer 21 
T-BC Telecom Boundary Clock 22 
TWAMP Two-Way Active Measurement Protocol 23 
UDP User Datagram Protocol 24 
UE User Equipment terminology for a mobile device in LTE and NR 25 
UL UpLink: data flow from the UE towards the core network, that is from the O -RU towards in the O-26 
DU in a Fronthaul context. 27

2 Test Configuration 1 
The conformance tests described in this document require test equipment with specific capabilities to support the testing 2 
of each protocol including the M-Plane, U-Plane, C-Plane and S-Plane. In addition, the tests define a specific 3 
connectivity between the test equipment and the device under test.  This section describes the test equipment 4 
requirements at a high level.  Details are included in each test.   5 
As noted in the introduction in the Scope paragraphs, the initial focus of the M-Plane, C-Plane and U-Plane 6 
conformance tests is the O-RU.  Version 2.00 and later include S-Plane tests for the O-DU in addition to the S-Plane 7 
tests for the O-RU.  The initial test configuration description below is focused on the test equipment and configuration 8 
required to test the O-RU. O-DU test configuration descriptions for the S-Plane are covered in the S-Plane section of 9 
this document. 10 
2.1 Test Configuration for O-RU as the Device Under Test 11 
When testing the O-RU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-RU (TER).  The TER is shown in  12 
Figure 2.1-1 below.   TER surrounds the DUT and connects to both the fronthaul interface itself and the radio interface. 13 
At the radio interface, the TER collects RF signals from the DUT (downlink) and sends RF signals to the DUT receiver 14 
(uplink).  Thus, the TER is made up of three main components, a CUSM-Plane Emulator (CUSM-E), a signal analyzer 15 
and a signal generator as shown in Figure 2.1-1. The RF test interface is described in TS 36.141 for LTE, TS 38.141-1 16 
for NR conducted, and TS 38.141-2 for non-conducted tests.  The fronthaul interface is standard Ethernet as described 17 
above.  In this case, the DL data flow is evaluated based on what is received by the signal analyzer in the RF domain as 18 
radiated by the O-RU, and the UL data flow is evaluated based on what is emitted by the signal generator in the RF 19 
domain and received by the CUSM-E.   20 
When the O-RU is the Device Under Test (DUT), there is Test Equipment, RU (“TER”) that is used to connect to the DUT, run the test 
and evaluate the test result.

▪ Collection of RF energy to determine if the O-RU reacted 
correctly to the DL C-Plane and U-Plane data
▪ Radiation of RF energy to be received by the O-RU (note: 
this could be actually radiated, or conveyed through 
multiple RF cabled connections)
▪ Collection of O-RU UL fronthaul data flows and evaluating 
it for correctness based on the supplied RF energy to the 
O-RU antennas or RF connectors

2.2 Test Configuration for O-DU as the Device Under Test 8 
When testing the open fronthaul interface of the O-DU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-DU 9 
(TED).  The TED is shown below with the following two cases:  10 
1. Stand-alone O-DU as the DUT – In this case the TED wraps around the O-DU DUT via its F1 interface 11 
towards the Core + O-CU Emulator (and additionally X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface 12 
towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity.  13 
2. Combined O-CU+O-DU (from the same vendor) as the DUT - In this case the TED wraps around the 14 
combined O-CU + O-DU DUT via the NG (SA) or S1 and X2 (NSA) interfaces towards the Core Emulator 15 
(additionally the X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, 16 
and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity.   17

 19 
 20 
Figure 2.2-2 Test Setup, DUT = O-DU 21 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 24 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
It is important to note that the tests assume production grade DUTs which should not be placed into any special test 2 
modes nor require any special test ports.  At the front haul interface, the O-RU+UE Emulator is expected to perform the 3 
following functions: 4 
1. Exchange of front haul data as required to exercise the feature under test.  This entails emulating the necessary 5 
front haul signals as seen by the O-DU DUT as if it were connected to an actual O-RU with an actual UE (or 6 
multiple UEs in the case of beamforming tests) performing an actual connection with the base station.   7 
2. Detailed observation and analysis of the front haul data stream of the O-DU DUT in order to ascertain 8 
compliance to the specifications.    9 
Note that in addition to the C-, U-, and M-plane signals in the fronthaul, this also includes the necessary S-plane for 10 
synchronizing the O-DU DUT with the O-RU+UE Emulator.   11 
Since the O-DU is meant to support various classes of O-RU with different feature sets, e.g. CAT-A or CAT-B, FR1 or 12 
FR2, different beamforming methods to multiple UEs, different compression schemes, etc.., it is important that the O -13 
RU+UE Emulator has the flexibility to effectively emulate the various scenarios in a robust and repeatable manner in 14 
order to test the various features.   Similarly, the Core+O-CU emulator (with the addition of an X2 signalling emulator 15 
for NSA mode) shall likewise emulate and observe the appropriate signals at the F1 or NG (or S1 and X2 for NSA) 16 
interfaces to effectively wrap-around the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT.  Note that the Core, O-CU, eNB, O-RU, and UE 17 
emulator functionalities required in the TED are those that place the O -DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT into a state that 18 
allows it to perform an actual connection(s) to a UE(s) to exercise the various open fronthaul features under test, and are 19 
thus not required to fully emulate the full functionality of their commercial equivalents.  Conversely , this specification 20 
does not preclude the use of the commercial equivalent elements instead of emulators, but must support a level of 21 
configurability and repeatability to ensure that the required features in the O-DU front-haul are effectively and 22 
repeatably exercised.  With use of either node emulators or commercial equivalents, the required test outcomes and 23 
reports must be effectively and repeatably reproduced.         24 
In order to cover the various potential optional features, section types, and section extensions for the O -DU DUT, the 25 
TED should use the O1 (if available) or EMS interface to provision the O -DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT in order to place it 26 
into the appropriate modes to exercise the specific features to test, which is then coordinated with the O -RU+UE 27 
Emulator in order to elicit the appropriate front-haul interface behavior.   28 
While M-Plane conformance tests do not generally require all the functions shown for a TE D inFigure 2.1-1, the intent 29 
of this description is to show the general capabilities required for all tests on the O -DU as the DUT including U-Plane, 30 
C-Plane and S-Plane tests.  If tests are restricted to only the M-Plane, the required test equipment configuration may be 31 
simplified. 32 
3 Conformance Measurements 33 
3.1 M-Plane Measurements 34 
The O-RAN Fronthaul management plane (M-Plane) protocol conformance tests are described in this section.   The M-35 
Plane is based on the NETCONF network element management protocol and YANG data modeling language.  The 36 
NETCONF protocol uses a client and server model for all exchanges of information and execution of RPCs.  Every 37 
NETCONF transaction is a 2-way exchange involving the client and the server.  The O-DU must support a NETCONF 38 
client and the O-RU must support a NETCONF server.  Any test written to exercise either the O-DU (client) or O-RU 39 
(server) is therefore applicable to both the O-DU and the O-RU.   40 
The following sections describe Conformance Tests for the M-Plane.   While all of these M-Plane conformance tests 41 
could apply to both the O-DU and the O-RU, some tests are focused primarily on the O-RU NETCONF server 42 
capabilities and functions.   Therefore, each test below is identified as a conformance test for the O -DU, the O-RU or 43 
both.  Table 1.2.4-1  lists all M-Plane test cases and whether they are applicable to one or both of the O-DU and O-RU 44 
for conformance testing. 45 
 46 
 47

3.1.1 Transport and Handshake Test Scenarios 1 
 Transport and Handshake in IPv4/SSH Environment (positive case) 2 
 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for a O-RU or O-DU that declares support for IPv4. 5 
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 6 
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments. 7 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 8 
• 6.2 Management Plane Transport aspects  9 
• 6.3 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 10 
 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 13 
configured and connected to the O-RU 14 
 15 
C. Test Methodology 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
1. The O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 18 
2. The configured DHCPv4 server is reachable by the O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN 19 
configured for M-Plane. 20 
3. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 21 
Client 22 
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the DHCP server). 23 
 24 
b. Procedure 25 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native ethernet 26 
or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover 27 
trying to reach the DHCP Server 28 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 29 
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 30 
3. O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER NETCONF Client 31 
from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 32 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure towards 33 
the NETCONF Client using the IP details obtained in step 3 34 
5. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a SSH session with the O-RU NETCONF Server.  Proper 35 
credentials are used. 36 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server accepts the SSH session establishment from the TER NETCONF Client 37 
7. The TER NETCONF Client and O-RU NETCONF Server exchange capabilities through NETCONF 38 
<hello> messages.  The following is an abbreviated example of the capabilities exchange.  A typical 39 
capabilities exchange will have far more parameters included. 40 
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 41

running:1.0</capability> 48 
    49 
<capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:notification:1.0</capabilit50 
y> 51 
    52

 Transport and Handshake in IPv4/SSH Environment (negative case) 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 20 
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 21 
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments.  Two negative flows are included in this test: 22 
• The TER NETCONF Client does not trigger a SSH session establishment in reaction to Call Home 23 
initiated by THE O-RU NETCONF Server. 24 
• The TER NETCONF Client uses improper credentials when trying to establish a SSH session with the O-25 
RU NETCONF Server. 26 
 27 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 28 
• 6.2 Management Plane Transport aspects 29 
• 6.3 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 30 
 31 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 32 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 33 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 34 
 35 
C. Test Methodology 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
a. O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 38 
b. Configured DHCPv4 server is reachable for O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN configured for 39 
M-Plane. 40 
c. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both O-RU NETCONF Server and NETCONF Client 41 
d. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to DHCP server). 42 
b. Procedure 43 
i. Flow 1 44 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native 45 
ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing a 46 
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 47 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 48 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 49 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of controlling TER NETCONF 50 
Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 51 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs Call Home procedure with 52 
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 53 
5. The TER NETCONF Client does not initiate the SSH session establishment procedure. 54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 27 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats the Call Home towards TER NETCONF Client.  1 
 2 
ii. Flow 2 3 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 4 
VLAN scan by issuing a DHCP Discover trying to reach the DHCP Server 5 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 6 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 7 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 8 
NETCONF Client from DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 9 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure 10 
with the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 11 
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates the SSH session establishment procedure with improper 12 
credentials. 13 
6. Due to the incorrect SSH credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the SSH session 14 
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 15 
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure towards the TER NETCONF 16 
Client. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 20 
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 21

VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 36 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 37 
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6  38 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure to 39 
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 40 
5. NETCONF Client does not initiate a TLS connection establishment procedure.  41 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats Call Home to the NETCONF Client.  42 
 43 
ii. Flow 2 44 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 45 
VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 46 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 47 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 48 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 49 
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6  50 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure to the 51 
TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 52 
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates a TLS connection establishment procedure with improper 53 
credentials.   54 
6. Due to the incorrect TLS credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the TLS connection 55 
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 56

7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure to the TER NETCONF Client.  1 
 2 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  3 
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 4 
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 5

 Retrieval with filter applied 15 
 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This scenario is MANDATORY 18 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly executes a get command with a filter applied. 19 
This is a general-purpose high-level test related to NETCONF implementation.  There is no direct relationship to a 20 
specific chapter in [3]: 21 
B. Minimum Requirements 22 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 23 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 24 
C. Test Methodology 25 
a. Initial Conditions 26 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) or 27 
3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS)  respectively is successfully completed. 28 
 29 
b. Procedure 30 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><get><filter> towards NETCONF Server.  The <filter> 31 
argument contains a regular expression that the O-RU NETCONF Server shall apply as a filter. For 32 
example, a filter that filters all low-level-rx-endpoints:  33 
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0" > 34 
      <get> 35 
          <source>running</source> 36 
          <filter type = ”subtree”> 37 
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0/”> 38 
                  <user-plane-configuration> 39 
                      <low-level-rx-endpoints> 40 
                      </low-level-rx-endpoints> 41 
                  </user-plane-configuration> 42 
              </top> 43 
          </filter> 44 
      </get> 45 
   </rpc> 46 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains details for objects 47 
as conforming to the <filter> (as per the above example filter: all low-level-rx-endpoints) 48 
 49 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 50 
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 51

3.1.5 Fault Management 1 
 O-RU Alarm Notification Generation  2 
 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 5 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly sends and alarm notification. 6 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7 
• 11.2 Alarm Notification 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12 
C. Test Methodology 13 
a. Initial Conditions 14 
i. The test procedure described in section 3.1.2.1 for Subscription to Notifications is successfully 15 
completed. 16 
ii. Testing with S-plane: Ensure that the alarm for fault id 17 is not already raised in the system. 17 
iii. Testing without S-plane: Ensure that the alarm for fault id which is triggered using a maintenance 18 
tool or debug command is not already raised in system. 19 
b. Procedure  20 
i) Testing with S-Plane: 21 
1. The TER NETCONF Client periodically tests O-RU’s sync-status until the LOCKED state is reached. 22 
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 23 
      <get> 24 
            <filter type = ”subtree”> 25 
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:sync:1.0/”> 26 
                  <sync><sync-status></sync-status></sync> 27 
              </top> 28 
          </filter> 29 
      </get> 30 
   </rpc> 31 
2. Disable the Sync signal on the TER. 32 
3. After a while (time depends on implementation) the O-RU NETCONF SERVER sends a notification for 33 
an alarm related to synchronization failure, e.g. alarm 17: No external sync source” or another vendor 34 
specific alarm.  The format of alarm notification follows RFC5277.   Note that the time in this example is 35 
shown generically and will be the current time during this test. 36 
 37 
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 38 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 39 
  <alarm-notif xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0"> 40 
    <fault-id>17</fault-id> 41 
    <fault-source>sync</fault-source> 42 
    <affected-objects> 43 
      <name>syncE</name> 44 
    </affected-objects> 45 
    <fault-severity>MAJOR</fault-severity> 46 
    <is-cleared>false</is-cleared> 47 
    <fault-text>No external sync source</fault-text> 48 
    <event-time> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </event-time> 49 
  </alarm-notif> 50 
</notification> 51 
 52 
ii) Testing without S-Plane: 53 
Note: Since this validation is for O-RU NETCONF Server properly sending the alarm notification, this is an 54 
alternative test method to testing with S-Plane. 55

3.1.9  External Input / Output Ports 13 
 External Input Port State Detection 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. The test is applicable only for O-RUs supporting logical input 16 
ports.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 17 
This test validates proper handling of logical input ports. 18 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 19 
• 14.5.2 External input 20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 23 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 24 
• Supplementary circuitry is required to force a change of logical state of input lines belonging to an input port. 25 
It is assumed that logical input ports are internally pulled to logical high state by O -RU, therefore 26 
supplementary circuitry shall only allow to change the input port to a logical low. To determine a physical 27 
input line for this test, one shall read the customer documentation applicable for the O-RU being tested. 28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 32 
 33 
b. Procedure 34 
1. The External Input Ports are left in their normal, default state.  For the purposes of this test, these input 35 
ports are assumed to be a logical high.  36 
2. The TER NETCONF Client retrieves state of chosen input port by issuing <rpc><get><filter 37 
type="subtree"><external-io xml...><input><port-in></port-in></input></external-38 
io></filter></get></rpc> 39 
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="7"> 40 
    <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 41 
    <filter type="subtree"> 42 
              <external-io xmlns:o-ran-io="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 43 
       <input>   <port-in/> </input> 44 
          </external-io> 45 
         </filter> 46 
           <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-47 
netconf-with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 48 
     </get> 49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 56 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
</rpc> 1 
 2 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server provides the state of every line-in belonging to the input port under test to 3 
the TER NETCONF Client. For all input lines, the state is TRUE, indicating open circuit (no shortage to 4 
ground is detected by input lines) 5 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-6 
id="7"> 7 
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 8 
    <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 9 
      <input> 10 
        <name>PORT0</name> 11 
        <port-in>0</port-in> 12 
        <line-in>TRUE</line-in> 13 
      </input> 14 
    </external-io> 15 
  </data> 16 
</rpc-reply> 17 
 18 
4. The TER supplementary circuitry randomly shorts one or more input lines to the ground. Changes shall 19 
occur with a periodicity greater than 30 seconds. 20 
5. For every change the O-RU NETCONF Server sends notification <external-input-change> to the TER 21 
NETCONF Client.   The notification contains updated states of input lines belonging to the port under test. 22 
A state FALSE indicates shortage to ground detected by particular input line. 23 
notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 24 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 25 
<external-input-change xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0" > 26 
      <current-input-notification > 27 
        <external-input > 28 
          <name > PORT0</name> 29 
            <line-in >FALSE</line-in> 30 
        </external-input> 31 
      </current-input-notification> 32 
    </external-input-change> 33 
</notification> 34 
 35 
6. This test scenario is looped to step 4 for a total of 10 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 36 
 37 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 38 
Step 5 is correctly validated for each of the total of 10 iterations of the test.  39

3.1.11 ALD Communications 19 
 ALD Communications Test 20 
A. Test Description and Applicability 21 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for a O-RU equipped with a RET port (regardless of whether 22 
this is a raw RS-485 port or OOK modem coupled internally to antenna connector(s)).  This scenario shall be 23 
performed against each ALD port exposed by the O-RU.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 24 
The purpose of the test is to validate the ALD communications protocol and operation of the O -RU. The following 25 
functions are validated in this test. 26 
• Proper transmission of the content if RPC <ald-communication> towards desired ALD port 27 
• Proper calculation of FCS 28 
• Proper application of basic transparency to content to be transmitted 29 
• Proper addition of start / stop flags 30 
• Proper reception of payload injected to ALD port 31 
• Proper removal of start / stop flags 32 
• Proper application of basic transparency to content received from ALD port 33 
• Proper validation of FCS in data received from ALD port. 34 
 35 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 36 
• 14.4 Operational aspects of Antenna Line Devices 37 
 38 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39 
• The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 40 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 41 
• It is assumed, that O-RU being a subject of this conformance test scenario is proven to be compliant to the 42 
following specifications: 43 
1. ISO/IEC 13239:2002 “High-level data link control (HDLC) procedures” 44 
2. 3GPP TS 25.460 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: General aspects and principles” 45 
3. 3GPP TS 25.461 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Layer 1” 46 
4. 3GPP TS 25.462 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Signalling Transport” 47 
5. 3GPP TS 25.466 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: Application Part” 48 
• The O-RU uses a 9.6 kbps data rate on its ALD port(s) for transmission and reception, regardless of connector 49 
supported by particular ALD port. 50 
 51 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 62 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
C. Test Methodology 2 
As O-RU does not verify correctness of the payload that is exchanged between NETCONF Client and ALD (except 3 
FCS for traffic coming from ALD) - any payload can be used in test vector, under condition, that test vectors are 4 
compliant to referenced above set of specification documents (e.g. length is not smaller than minimum size of real 5 
message). 6 
RS-485 sniffer / injector is needed for this test. Such a device shall be connected either to O -RU’s RS-485 port or 7 
to RS-485 port of Smart BiasT connected to O-RU with coaxial cable (depending on O-RU construction) 8 
Unless not specified otherwise – RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port corresponding to record 9 
“port-id” used in RPC <ald-communication>. 10 
In case O-RU exposes ALD port as antenna port, test environment should utilize Smart BiasT for conversion 11 
between OOK modulation at antenna port and RS-485 signaling that RS-485 sniffer / injector can handle. DC 12 
voltage for Smart BiasT device shall be provided by O-RU through antenna feeder. 13 
If not specified otherwise, for test purposes RS-485 sniffer / injector is connected to ALD port which will be 14 
addressed in RPC <ald-communication> within the scenario. 15 
As this test is intended to verify O-RU functions and there will be no real ALD connected – compliance to the 16 
required HDLC message structure is required, whilst the AISG payload can be artificial (unless otherwise specified 17 
in test case). The O-RU does not verify if messaging is correct, hence, for test simplicity and ease of test result 18 
verification, artificial test vectors can be used. 19 
a. Initial Conditions 20 
a. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 21 
 22 
b. Procedure 23 
i. Test Case 1: Transmission towards ALD (positive scenario) 24 
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram  25 
transmission using desired ALD port  26 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message containing bytes 0x7D and 27 
0x7E in “ald-req-msg” record. 28 
2) O-RU calculates FCS, adds it to datagram provided in record “ald-req-msg”, applies basic 29 
transparency (replaces every occurrence of byte “0x7E” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5E”, respectively, 30 
replace byte “0x7D” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5D”) and add start/stop flags 0x7E.  31 
3) O-RU sends payload calculated in step 2 through ALD port mentioned in record “port -id” of RPC. 32 
4) RS-485 sniffer / injector receives payload sent by O-RU. Received payload is subject of analysis for 33 
scenario success / failure classification 34 
 35 
ii. Test Case 1 Test Requirement (expected result) 36 
Content received by RS-485 listener / injector is compared with content of RPC <ald-communication>. 37 
a) payload shall be sent by desired ALD port of O-RU 38 
b) FCS shall be properly calculated 39 
c) basic transparency shall be properly applied 40 
d) start / stop flags shall be added to payload that has been received by RS-485 sniffer / injector 41 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 42 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 43 
 44 
iii. Test Case 2: Reception from ALD (positive case) 45 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorithm applications, 46 
CRC verification  47 
Note: Test case 2 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS -485 sniffer / 48 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 49 
between Test case 1 and Test case 2 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above.  50 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 63 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
1) RS485 sniffer / injector sends properly formatted (start / stop flags, FCS and min / max payload size) 1 
message containing strings “0x7D 0x5E” and “0x7D 0x5D” towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 2 
case 1. 3 
2) O-RU receives the content. 4 
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” 5 
and “0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”), makes sure if FCS is correct according content of datagram.  6 
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client.  In the response parameter “status” contains 7 
value “ACCEPTED”. 8 
 9 
iv. Test Case 2 Requirement (expected result) 10 
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS -485 sniffer / injector. 11 
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 12 
b) basic transparency is properly applied 13 
b) counter of received octets is properly incremented 14 
d) counters of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) and frames without stop flags are not incremented  15 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 16 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 17 
v. Test Case 3: Reception from ALD (negative case – wrong FCS) 18 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorith m application, 19 
CRC verification  20 
Note: Test case 3 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS -485 sniffer / 21 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 22 
between Test case 1 and Test case 3 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above. 23 
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message containing wrong FCS towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 24 
case 1. 25 
2) O-RU receives the content. 26 
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” and 27 
“0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”) and detects, that FCS is incorrect according content of received datagram.  28 
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client.  In the response parameter “status” contains 29 
value “ACCEPTED”. 30 
 31 
vi. Test Case 3 Requirement (expected result) 32 
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS -485 sniffer / injector. 33 
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 34 
b) record “ald-resp-msg” is empty 35 
b) counter of frames without stop flags is not incremented 36 
d) counter of received octet and counter of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) are incremented 37 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 38 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 39 
 40 
vii. Test Case 4: Reception from ALD (negative case – no stop flag) 41 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection 42

© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
Note: Test case 4 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS-485 sniffer / 1 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 2 
between Test case 1 and Test case 4 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above.  3 
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message not terminated by stop flag “0x7E” towards O-RU’s ALD port 4 
used in Test case 1. 5 
2) O-RU receives the content. 6

ix. Test case 5: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – wrong ALD port) 21 
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram 22 
transmission using desired ALD port (ports are not used by the same HDLC Primary Device)  23 
Scenario is applicable only in case O-RU supports more than one ALD port and under condition that ALD 24 
ports do not share single modem. 25 
IMPORTANT: In this scenario RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port different from 26 
than the one indicated in record “port-id” of RPC <ald-communication>. 27 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. 28 
2) O-RU performs the content processing and sends the content towards ALD port that corresponds to 29 
content of record “port-id” of RPC 30 
3) RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive payload sent by O-RU.  31 
 32 
x. Test Requirement (expected result) 33 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive 34 
payload in step 3. Any deviation is considered as failed test case. 35 
 36 
xi. Test case 6: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – non-existing ALD port) 37 
Scope: datagram reception 38 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. Parameter <port-id> used in 39 
RPC does not point to existing ALD port. 40 
2) O-RU sends <rpc-error> to NETCONF Client. In the response parameter “error-tag” contains value 41 
“data-missing”. 42 
3) NETCONF Client receives the <rpc-error> message as described above. 43

3.1.13 Connectivity Check 15 
 Ethernet Connectivity Monitoring 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY if the O-RU or O-DU supports C-Plane and U-Plane 18 
connectivity over Ethernet.   19 
This test validates the proper operation of LBM on the O-RU. 20 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 21 
• 7.3 C/U Plane VLAN configuration 22 
• 7.5 Definition of processing elements 23 
• 7.6.1 C/U-Plane transport connectivity verification 24 
 25 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 26 
1. The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 27 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 28 
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 29 
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 30 
 31 
C. Test Methodology 32 
a. Initial Conditions 33 
The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 34 
 35 
b. Procedure 36 
1. The TER NETCONF Client configures the O-RU NETCONF Server with a vlan-id for the C-Plane and 37 
U-Plane interfaces. 38 
2. The TER NETCONF Client configures a transport-flow in the O-RU processing element:  a combination 39 
of VLAN identity, O-DU MAC address and O-RU MAC address.  40 
3. The TER sends loopback message to the O-RU MAC address configured for the processing element. 41 
4. The O-RU sends loopback responses to the O-DU MAC Address of the loopback message. 42 
 43 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 44 
Packets are sent correctly in step 3 and 4, as validated via the TER. 45

This test validates the proper operation UDP Echo on the O-RU for continuous verification of connectivity. 5

• 7.6 O-DU Verification of C/U Plane Transport Connectivity 9 
 10

operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 13 
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 14 
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 15 
 16

 20

for the C-Plane and U-Plane communications.  23

Server. 25 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends back the UDP datagram to the TER NETCONF Client. 26 
 27

3.2 UC-Plane Measurements O-RU 2 
3.2.1 UC-Plane Standard Test Definitions 3 
The following sections describe test scenarios for equipment implementing the U -Plane and C-Plane O-RAN option 4 
7.2x protocols.    5 
 UC-Plane Measurements, O-RU TEST SCENARIO 6 
In these sets of tests, the Device Under Test (DUT) is the O-RU.   7 
This document describes conformance tests for 4 scenarios: 8 
1. Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios 9 
2. Non-conducted (OTA) FDD tests for FR1 radios 10 
3. Conducted TDD tests for FR1 radios 11 
4. Non-conducted tests for TDD FR1 and FR2 radios 12 
 13 
The O-RU must only be tested for the scenarios that apply to the O-RU capabilities. The fact that there are 4 scenarios 14 
defined does not imply that every O-RU must be tested for all scenarios in order to be O-RAN compliant and 15 
consequently the O-RU does not have to support all the capabilities required to test all 4 scenarios (i.e. support of FR1, 16 
FR2, TDD, FDD, conducted and non-conducted). In other words, depending on whether the O-RU supports capabilities 17 
such as FDD, TDD, FR1 and or FR2, only the corresponding scenarios that match the O-RU capabilities will apply. For 18 
example, an O-RU that does not have or cannot provide access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), supports TDD 19 
and operates at FR2 bands, the corresponding scenario that the O-RU will need to be tested to be O-RAN conformant is 20 
scenario #4 only. Another example, for an O-RU that supports FDD, operates at FR1 bands and has or can provide 21 
access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), scenario #1 or #2 can apply but only one of the two possible  scenarios will 22 
be selected to test the O-RU for O-RAN conformance.   23 
For scenario #1 and #3 above the RF test setup is as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  For 24 
scenarios #2 and #4 the RF test setup is as described in TS 38.141-2. Note that O-RAN conformance testing is expected 25 
to be “off-line” and not to be run while an O-DU and/or O-RU is operating and serving actual users.  The O-RU 26 
manufacturer must also make available the same declarations described in 3GPP TS 38.141 -1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and 27 
TS 36.141 [LTE] Section 4.6.  This will determine the radio’s support for multi -carrier operation (e.g., if multi-carrier 28 
operation is supported on different connectors) 29 
Since the purpose of this document is to test O-RAN Fronthaul conformance and not to duplicate 3GPP RF tests, only 30 
selected parts of TS 38.141-1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] will be used for RF testing.  These selected test 31 
features are only necessary to test whether the O-RU correctly interpreted and generated the O-RAN C-Plane and U-32 
Plane messages correctly. Several testcases require a bandwidth that may not be supported by the O -RU. In such 33 
situation, the testcase should be executed by adjusting to a bandwidth that is supported by the O -RU and complies with 34 
the channel bandwidth listed in either TS 38.104 section 5.3.2 for NR or TS 36.104 section 5.6 for LTE. The adjustment 35 
of the bandwidth can be done by reducing the number of physical resource blocks or by selecting another FRC. The 36 
bandwidth adjustment may select the minimum bandwidth defined by 3GPP. The adjustment of the bandwidth does not 37 
require the execution of the same testcase again with a larger bandwidth. 38 
There will also be some additions to the test waveforms used in TS 38.141 -1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] 39 
to fully exercise the features of the O-RAN Fronthaul protocol.  These selected parts and additions are summarized 40 
below: 41 
 For scenario #1 (Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios) 42 
• For downlink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 43 
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.1.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 44 
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 45 
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 46 
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 47

 72

• For uplink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 1 
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.2.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 2 
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 3 
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 4 
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 5 
• For downlink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 6 
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.3.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 7 
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 8 
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 9 
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio dist ribution network 10 
(RDN). 11 
• For uplink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 12 
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.4.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 13 
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 14 
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 15 
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio distribution network 16 
(RDN). 17 
• The basic downlink test will start with the Test model described in NR-FR1-TM1.1 and E-TM1.1.  Subsequent 18 
tests will adapt this model to test additional features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, 19 
blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not 20 
the O-RAN specific parameters.  This test model will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific 21 
parameters: 22 
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 23 
• DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 24 
• BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 25 
• CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier)  26 
• RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a 27 
specific test 28 
• If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. 29 
Note that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]  require testing at the bottom, 30 
middle and top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification r elaxes that requirement because the 31 
purpose is to test the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 32 
• Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 33 
• Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the 34 
antenna surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to 35 
unity) 36 
• Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 37 
• Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay 38 
is considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and 39 
T34_min = T34_max = 0. 40 
The radio will report its supported values for: 41 
o T2a_min/max_up 42 
o Ta3_min/max_up 43 
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 44 
o Tcp_adv_dl 45 
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.   46 
Note that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  47 
Similarly, Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Similarly, T1a_min_cp_ul = 48 
T2a_min_cp_ul and T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   49 
 50 
• Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and 51 
in-channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  All O-RAN specific 52 
parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing.  As with downlink testing subsequent 53 
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 54

• Note that the chamber shown in TS 38.141-2 E1.2. and E.2.1. are generic and consequently any OTA chamber 40 
could be used, i.e. far field, CATR, near field, reverberation, etc. 41

E.2.1. may or may not be needed. 43

Table 3.2.1.1-1 Configuration Parameters for TDD FR1 Conducted Tests 1 
This waveform is shown below: 2 
 3 
Figure 3.2.1.1-1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 TDD Test Signal 4 
 5 
As an alternative to the default test waveform shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-1, it is optional to flexibly use other test 6 
waveforms with any TDD configurations allowed by the information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined 7 
in TS 38.331 for 30 kHz SCS. The tester should use the 3GPP prescribed waveform as the recommended waveform but 8 
has the option to use any TDD configuration in the IOT profiles defined in [25] with the above constraints. 9 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 10 
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds to 11 
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 below) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 12 
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described in section 3.2.3.1 13 
the stock test frames can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used. Symbols number two and 14 
eleven contain DMRS signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test 15 
equipment synchronize.  In the standard test frame, all PDSCH data is set to zeros if not otherwise described in the 16 
testcase and PUSCH is set to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation 17 
test) the PN23 sequence will be used in both uplink and downlink to allow the test to determine whether test data was 18 
put in the correct PRBs and whether the test data was accurately transmitted (or received) by the O -RU under test. 19 
• For tests for type 1-C and 1-H the test configuration described in TS 38.141-1 for TDD testing will be used.  Only a 20 
single antenna port will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more 21 
than one port.  RF test equipment will be connected at the point described in TS 38.141 -1. Note that an antenna 22 
port is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element.  23 
• The test will start with the Test model described above.  Subsequent tests will adapt this model to test additional 24 
features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test 25

tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 31 
• Uplink tests will be conducted using power levels at least 30dB higher than the power levels used to test 3GPP 32 
Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. This is to ensure a 33 
clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure the correct data 34 
was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests is to ensure correct 35

This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 6 
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This config uration corresponds to 7 
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 below) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 8 
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described the stock test frames 9 
can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used.  Symbols number two and eleven contain DMRS 10 
signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test equipment synchronize.  11

to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation test) the PN23 sequence 13

 Test Configuration for the UC-Plane 1 
The TER shown in Figure 2.1-1 provides M-Plane and S-Plane commands and sequences to correctly set up the O-RU 2 
for testing using the fronthaul connection – meaning a criterion and prerequisite for executing all UC-Plane tests is 3 
proper operation of the O-RU’s synchronization and M-Plane capabilities.  The TER provides the specific C-Plane and 4 
U-Plane data flows and collects data from the radiated energy from the O-RU and evaluates based on the collected RF 5 
energy whether the O-RU correctly received and interpreted the fronthaul DL data flow.  For many tests a single RF 6 
detector is satisfactory to detect the radiated signal but for beamforming tests an RF pattern must be measured to 7 
validate the correct beam is being generated according to the C-Plane commands and U-Plane data flowing across the 8 
fronthaul interface. 9 
In addition, the TER generates RF energy using the signal generator and feeds it to the O -RU’s antennas (or antenna 10 
connectors) which is expected to be used by the O-RU, in conjunction with the C-Plane UL commands sent by the TER 11 
over the fronthaul connection, to generate UL data flows on the fronthaul connection which are received and evaluated 12 
by the TER.  For almost all tests a single RF emitter is satisfactory to generate the radiated signal, even beamforming 13 
tests wherein the received power level will validate that the beam main lobe was correctly specified across the fronthaul 14 
interface, except for the case of uplink channel-information-based beamforming tests where multiple RF emitters are 15 
needed to emulate multiple uplink spatial streams. 16 
3GPP-specified tests will be used here to simplify the testing, because such tests will need to be supported by the O -RU 17 
anyway for 3GPP conformance testing.  The specific test cases identify where this is possible and where changes must 18 
be made to adequately test O-RAN features. 19 
Note that when testing the O-RU for fronthaul interface conformance, much more than the fronthaul interface is being 20 
tested, indeed the entire O-RU is under test, including digital and analog processing having nothing to do with the 21 
fronthaul interface.  Therefore a “passed” test can be interpreted with some confidence as indicating a properly 22 
operating fronthaul interface, but a “failed” test may indicate a problem with the fronthaul interface or with some other 23 
operation within the O-RU therefore failed tests may require some troubleshooting.  While 3GPP TS 38.141-1, TS 24 
38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] describes the basic waveform used in these tests it does not describe how the 25 
various channels should be put into O-RAN sections.  The 3GPP TS 38.141-1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 [NR FR1], TS 38.141-2 26 
NR-FR2-TM1.1 [NR FR2], and TSTS 36.141 E-TM1.1 [LTE] signals are tightly packed with data.  All tests will divide 27 
that data into “stock” data sections using the sections described below.   To expedite the definition and creation of the 28 
tests, a set of standard test environments and patterns is defined in this section.  This includes a “stock” arrangement of 29 
data sections in DL (same is used for UL) which can be used regardless of the specific bandwidth and SCS used  in the 30 
test.  Specifically, there are “stock” 1-symbol, 2-symbol, and 3-symbol data section sets that shall be cited in test 31 
definitions (numbered “A” through “F”) that will support various test cases.  The test cases are expected to specify the 32 
data section definition of a test slot and all slots are expected to follow the same data section definition unless a test 33 
specifically states otherwise.  In many cases only some symbols within a slot will be subject to testing; the remaining  34 
symbols are expected to remain undefined for the test and may have data sections defined according to the normal 35 
operation of the O-DU (e.g. set to carry synch or reference signals consistent with LTE or NR).  In cases where a 36 
specific type of data section cannot be supported by the DUT, then that data section is omitted in the symbol(s) and the 37 
corresponding U-Plane data shall be set to zero in DL (and arranged to have no RF power in UL).  Figure 3.2.1.1-2 38 
shows the “stock” data section definition. 39

B: 1 symbol 2 sections : slightly more complex

D: 1 symbol many sections : tests single-PRB section, rb bit, use of non-all-ones reMask, many data sections
E: 2 symbol 2 sections : tests multi-symbol section, symIncbit
F: 3 symbols many sections : tests data gaps, reMask, multi-symbol sections

Figure 3.2.1.1-2 Stock Data Section Definition for both DL and UL 2 
 3 
There is also “stock” U-Plane data that is PN23 data, representing user data prior to modulation, as specified within 4 
3GPP 38.14138.141-1[CCITT Recommendation O.151 (10/92): https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-O.151-199210-I/en] 5 
which is assumed to start at a frame boundary and be identical in all frames in both DL and UL, unless a specific test 6 
states differently.  The PN sequence is expected to be running for the duration of the frame for whatever is the 7 
bandwidth and SCS (this is different from how the data sections are handled, wherein the data sections are truncated 8 
based on the number of PRBs per symbol).  However, in many cases only some symbols within a frame will be actually 9 
subject to testing (as defined by the specific tests) so will contain the test PN sequence data; the remaining symbols are 10 
expected to remain undefined for the test and may contain data according to the normal operation of the O -DU (e.g. set 11 
to carry synch or reference signals consistent with LTE or NR).  Note that the PN sequence initial value is provided by 12 
a seed which may be included as a Test Command parameter. If the parameter is omitted t he PN sequence generator 13 
will use a “seed” value of all ones. 14 
For all tests, the test definition shall define the specific slots and symbols subject to test (carrying the “stock” C-Plane 15 
data section definition and the “stock” U-Plane data) with the remaining slots and symbols carrying normal 3GPP synch 16 
and control data and either allocated user data according to 3GPP or left empty (i.e. no user data allocated).  All slots 17 
and symbols subject to test are identical in each frame, so tests do not have to wait for a specific frame number and are 18 
not expected to reset or otherwise perturb the normal frame number seque nce.  This is intended to allow the test to 19 
disrupt normal O-DU and O-RU operation as little as possible. If there is a specific need to validate the construction of 20 
a specific frame or slot of data, a test may elect to zero the test data and leave undefin ed the data sections for all except 21 
one slot or frame of data; where this is necessary it will be described in the specific test definition, but this is expected  22 
to be an exceptional case. 23 
 Generic Steps for Test Execution, O-RU TEST SCENARIO 24 
The following are the generic test steps used when testing the O-RU, although specific tests may deviate from this 25 
general procedure: 26 
1) Configure the Test Equipment, O-RU (TER) for test execution, which may include defining the specific test to 27 
execute. This may also include using a scripting language for describing the test. 28 
2) Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 29 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 30 
3) Send appropriate C-Plane and U-Plane DL data flows and collect the O-RU radiated energy (or collect from 31 
antenna connectors) using RF detection equipment. 32 
4) Evaluate the RF energy pattern from the O-RU to determine if the O-RU correctly received and interpreted the 33 
fronthaul C-Plane and U-Plane data flows.  In some cases, it also includes decoding and demodulating the RF 34 
signal to ensure all UC-Plane messages were interpreted correctly. 35 
5) Send appropriate C-Plane messages to define the desired UL U-Plane flow, at the same time cause the RF 36 
signal generator to radiate (or feed into antenna connectors) the appropriate RF energy pattern  for the test.  37 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 81 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
This also means meeting the appropriate timing windows to allow the O-RU to decode and process the C-1 
Plane messages before the signal generator starts sending RF. 2 
6) Collect the O-RU UL data flows on the fronthaul interface and evaluate for correctness; this will generally be 3 
U-Plane data only but in limited cases (LAA) may include UL C-Plane messages too. 4 
7) Since FDD uplink and TDD tests require tight timing constraints between the components of the TER it is 5 
recommended that CUSM emulator signal the RF test equipment when C -Plane signalling has started for a 6 
frame.  How this signal is used by the RF test equipment to synchronize transmission and reception is 7 
implementation dependant. 8 
 9 
 10 
3.2.2 Minimum Capabilities of the TER for U-Plane and C-Plane Tests 11 
Since many features of the O-RAN protocol rely on the O-DU instructing the O-RU to put data in specific resource 12 
blocks using a specific compression method it is imperative that the test equipment support features that allow 13 
comparing data on the fronthaul side with data on the RF side of the radio. 14 
 Signal Analyzer 15 
• Must have the capability of decoding and demodulating an RF signal either received over the air or on a 16 
conducted interface.  This data must be made available for comparison with data sent on the fronthaul 17 
interface. 18 
• Must be able to determine the Phase and amplitude of any signal for beamforming tests. 19 
• Obviously must support the frequency range of the radio being tested. 20 
 Signal Generator 21 
• Must provide software capable of building a correct 5G or LTE waveform. 22 
• Should have the ability to automatically build 3GPP compliant test waveforms and should provide a 23 
mechanism for editing the parameters of that waveform. 24 
• Must be able to be synchronized with the O-DU emulator to ensure proper timing of uplink C-Plane and U-25 
Plane messages 26 
 CUSM-Plane Emulator (CUSM-E) 27 
• Must be able to extract IQ data from uplink U-Plane messages and demodulate and decode the data to ensure it 28 
is the same as what was commanded in the uplink C-Plane messages. 29 
• Must have the ability to synchronize with the RF signal source. 30 
• Should have the ability to perform as a PTP Master or subordinate depending on the synchronization 31 
configuration the radio supports. 32 
• Must have the ability to accept frequency domain IQ and encapsulate it according to user input on the correct 33 
sections. 34 
 35 
3.2.3 FR1 FDD Conducted-Signal Tests  36 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG)  37 
Note that all downlink tests in this section use a 3GPP test wave form with 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz 38 
Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP 38.141 -1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 and section 3.2.1.1.5 of this document.  There are 39 
several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If the radio does not support the 40 
numerology used in the example tests as reported in the M-plane it will be up to the test developer to modify their tests 41 
to adapt to the radio.  This can usually be accomplished by using stock test patters described above.  The test is 42 
expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document but things like symbol numbers, number of PRBs, etc. 43 
may have to be changed. 44 
All uplink tests in this section use a 3GPP test waveform described in 38.141-1 section A1, in particular G-FR1-A1-5 45 
(30 kHz subcarrier spacing, QPSK, 100 MHz BW). As with downlink tests if the radio does not support this signal it is 46 
up to the test developer to modify the parameters of the test without changing the spirit of the test. 47

This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic downlink requirements for O-RAN fronthaul.  5 
Subsequent tests will build on this to exercise additional capabilities of the Fronthaul.  6 
 7 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 8 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 9 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal.  This signal is shown below in Figure 3.2.3.1-1. 10 
 11 
 12 
Figure 3.2.3.1-1  NR-FR1-TM1.1 FDD Test Signal 13 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 14 
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds 15 
to stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 above) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. If the radio 16 
does not support the numerology described in section 3.2.3.1 the stock test frames can be adapted for smaller 17 
numbers of PRBs and should still be used. 18 
 19 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame using the default parameters in 20 
section 3.2.1.1.5 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial stream on one antenna 21 
will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  As per 22 
TM-FR1-TM1.1 all user data in this test will be zeros. 23 
 24 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 25 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The test numerology will be 26 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New 27 
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  28 
 29 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.  It must 30 
also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 31 
 32

1. Initial Conditions 34 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 35 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 36

O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 1

2. Procedure 3

 UC Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL 37 
A. Test Description and Applicability 38 
This test is MANDATORY. 39 
 40 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink requirements for O -RAN fronthaul 41 
correctly interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal. 42 
Subsequent tests will build on this to exercise additional capabilities of the Fronthaul. 43 
 44 
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 45 
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 46 
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 47 
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 48 
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  49

Leverage from the well-known payload (PN23 sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the payload of the 28 
signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane message and 29 
demodulated to retrieve payload.  30 
  31 
a: Initial Conditions 32

port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 35

PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. 21

all symbols have user data allocated, every symbol may be described by either multiple or a single type 1 9 
section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #5 and #6 which will be used for the SymInc test. The data in 10 
these sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. Each symbol should be a new PN23 11 
sequence, that is PRB 0 should contain the data from a new PN23 sequence for each symbol. No section type 12 
zero messages will be used for this test. 13 
 14 
Symbols number 5 and 6 should be stock data sections type “E” as shown  above.  This stock data section 15 
consists of two adjacent symbols each containing two sections.  The corresponding C-Plane message will 16

application header will be symbol #5. The third section ID for symbol #6 will have the SymInc bit set 18 
informing the O-RU that the third section will begin describing symbol #6.  19
