C. Test Methodology 25 
Leverage from the well-known payload (Pseudo Random sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the 26 
payload of the signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane 27 
message and demodulated to retrieve payload.  28 
  29 
a. Initial Conditions 30 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-31 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 32 
port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 33 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 34 
receiver sensitivity test. 35 
 36 
b. Procedure 37 
• Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS130k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal 38 
should contain a new PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 51 for symbols 6 and 7.  The remainder 39 
of the test waveform may be left unallocated or allocated as described in 3GPP. 40 
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger 41 
signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 42 
• Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Use the O-DU emulator control 43 
interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. For this test symbols number 6 44 
and 7 will be used in each slot.  The starting PRB will be zero and number of PRBs will be 2 73.  The 45 
resource block group size will be 16.  Using the calculations in the O-RAN CUS Specification [2], clause 46 
7.7.6, the ID of the last RBG will be 17, f(0) will be 16, f(n) will be 16 and f(lastRbgID) will be 1.  StartPrbc 47 
will be zero and numPrbc will be 273. 48 
If symbols other than #6 and #7 are allocated, every symbol should be described by multiple type 1 section 49 
(DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #6 and #7 which will be used for the section extension 6 test. The data in 50 
symbol #6 is expected to be a new PN23 sequence starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 48 (RBG 51 
number 2).  Symbol #7 should be identical to symbol #6.  The rbgMask value should be set to 52 
0000000000000000000000000101b  and the symbolMask value should be set to 00000011000000b.  No 53 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 54 
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  55 
• Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and trigger the source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  56 
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  57 
• Extract IQ information  58 
• Extract Payload 59

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Extension 10 – Multiple Port Grouping DL – 11 
Resource allocation 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages when 16 
section extension 10 is supported by the radio, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit 17 
this data accurately in the downlink.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is 18 
required).  The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  Note the 19 
purpose of this test is not to test the use of section extension 10 with either section extension 1 or 2 (Real time 20 
beam weights or attributes) since these are special conditions.  There are three versions of beam  groupings: 21 
Common Beam, beam matrix indication or beam vector listing.  Each of these will be tested.  The beamforming 22 
measurements will be conducted using the method described in section 3.2.3.2.3 and 3.2.3.2.4 (Predefined 23 
beamforming). 24 
 25 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 26 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 27 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal.  This signal is shown below in Figure 3.2.3.1-12. 28

 12 
There will be numPortc “layers” or eAxCs referred to in the test.  That is there will be one C-Plane message 13 
referencing the port group eAxC ID obtained from the M-Plane but numPortc U-Plane messages. 14 
 15 
Manufacturers’ must provide their defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation 16

 19 
C. Test Methodology 20 
 21 
a. Initial Conditions 22 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-23 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 24 
antenna ports being tested and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch 25 
and demodulate the transmitted signal.  Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is 26 
phase coherence between the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  Let the DUT and 27 
TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 28 
b. Procedure 29 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  30 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane message that describes the signal.  31 
This message should include section extension 10. Note the test will be performed three times exercising all 32 
three beam group types. Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using 33 
section type 1 messages. The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. No 34 
section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for each 35 
layer (i.e., numPortc repetitions).  36 
 37 
Test case #1 (beamGroupType = 00b, Common Beam): 38 
For this test the beamGroupType parameter should be set to 00b. It is expected that all layers will be played on 39 
the same beam ID and this is the beam ID used in the corresponding C-Plane message. Play those messages to 40 
the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of 41 
times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  Use the 42 
signal analyzer to decode at least two beams and ensure they are the same. 43 
 44 
Test case #2 (beamGroupType = 01b, beam matrix indication): 45 
For this test the beamGroupType parameter should be set to 01b. It is expected that all layers will be played  on 46 
consecutive beam IDs starting with the beam ID in the C-Plane message. Play those messages to the O-RU 47 
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 48 
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  Use the signal 49 
analyzer to decode at least two beams and ensure they meet the consecutive beam criteria. 50 
 51 
Test case #3 (beamGroupType = 10b, beam vector listing): 52 
For this test the beamGroupType parameter should be set to 10b. In this case the section extension should list 53 
“numPortc” beam IDs in section extension 10.  It is expected that all layers will be played on the be am IDs 54 
indicated in the section extension. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in 55 
section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow 56 
it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  Use the signal analyzer to decode at least two beams and ensure 57 
they agree with the beam vector listing. 58

Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-30 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 31 
port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 32 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 33 
receiver sensitivity test. 34 
b: Procedure 35 
• Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS30k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source  36 
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 37 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 38 
• Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) C-Plane messages will contain valid 39 
values in the following fields: 40 
• EAxC ID 41 
• Datadirection bit (Uplink) 42 
• Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 43 
• SectionID must have a value 4095 44 
• SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 45 
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  46 
• Launch test to play the RF uplink frame after the C-Plane messages have been sent honoring timing 47 
windows  48 
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  49 
• TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 50 
• Extract IQ information  51 
• Extract Payload 52 
• Compare payload binary sequences  53 
  54 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  55 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 56 
DUT and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 57 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail"  58

 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource allocation – Section 3 
Description Priorities  4 
A. Test Description and Applicability 5 
This test is CONDITIONAL  MANDATORY. 6 
 7 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 8 
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink  when the 9 
radio reports it supports the option feature of coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section  10 
Description Priorities.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  11 
The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is mandatory the radio 12 
pass this test if it reports it supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency .  Note, there are two versions 13 
of this feature: coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities and 14 
coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities (optimized).  This test 15 
requires both tests to be performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise only one test is to be performed if 16 
the radio only supports one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test methodology below. 17 
 18 
 19 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 20 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 21 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal with exceptions noted in the test procedure.  This signal is shown 22 
below in Figure 3.2.3.1-16 . 23

 UC-Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Section Description Priorities 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the uplink requirements for O -RAN fronthaul correctly 5 
interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal when the 6 
radio reports it supports Section Description Priorities as well as Coupling C and U plane via time and frequency.  7 
Note, there are two versions of this feature: coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section 8 
Description Priorities and coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description 9 
Priorities (optimized).  This test requires both tests to be performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise 10 
only one test is to be performed in the radio only supports one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test 11 
methodology below.  12 
 13 
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 14 
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 15 
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 16 
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 17 
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  18 
 19 
 20 
 21 
Figure 3.2.3.1-17  G-FR1-A1-5 Uplink FDD Test Signal 22 
 23 
This signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the power increased 24 
to up to 30 dB above that described in Table 7.2.5-1.  Under those conditions, a 3GPP compliant O-RU should 25 
deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches the uplink signal. Note this is the starting signal however it will be 26 
modified as described below to accommodate this test. 27 
 28 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, together 29 
with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 30 
 31 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the 32 
uplink signal as well as beam characteristics signals in the C-Plane.  33

downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal with the modifications described below (supporting non-contiguous 27 
PRB allocation)..  The standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 is shown in Figure 3.2.3.1-18 below: 28

 UC Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Static SRS allocation 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 19 
 20 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 21 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for FDD.  Th e O-RU must report through the M-Plane 22 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 23 
 24 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 25 
resources reserved for static uplink SRS.  The signal source will be programmed to send simulated SRS signals in a 26 
subset of those resources.  The O-RU should receive this SRS signals and pass them through to the CUSM emulator 27 
using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from the CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  28 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in 1 
TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly 2 
since we are not interested in testing receiver sensitivity but only the O -RAN protocol compliance. 3 
 4 
The placement of the time frequency resources is not specified in this test so it may be placed anywhere in the 5 
frame. 6 
 7 
 8 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 9 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 10 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that th e signal received by the CUSM emulator 11 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 12 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physi cal 13 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 14 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chance of false 15 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 16 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O -RU. 17 
 18 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 20 
supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as 21 
described in section 3GPP TS 138.141-1 section G-FR1-A-5.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must 22 
have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal may be changed to any of the 3GPP 23 
sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 138.141-1 if the radio does not support the numerology and 24 
bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the radio supports that 25 
numerology and bandwidth. 26 
C. Test Methodology 27 
  28 
a: Initial Conditions 29 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-30 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 31 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 32 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 33 
receiver sensitivity test. 34 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 35 
SRS signals. 36 
b: Procedure 37 
• Build an SRS signal in the signal generator that fits in the preconfigured time frequency resources set in the 38 
initial configuration. 39 
• Load the waveform into the signal source: 40 
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 41 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that signals the start of a frame boundary. 42 
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  43 
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port 44 
connected 45 
• TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 46 
• Start SRS waveform generation on the signal generator. Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times to 47 
generate a statistically significant number of SRS occasions. That is at least 10 occasions.  48 
• Extract IQ information  49 
• Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 50 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation.  51 
  52 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  53 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8% as median EVM measured over the minimum 54 
number of SRS occasions of at least 10 occasions.. 55 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail"  56

A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 5 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for FDD.  The O -RU must report through the M-6 
Plane capabilities that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat test 3.2.3.8.1 (5GNR  7 
PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-Plane. 8 
 9 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141 -1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 10 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 11 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 12 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3, at each occasion the time offset of the 13 
same preamble index (selected according to table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up 14 
to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub -frames. The 15 
scheme is repeated every frame. 16 
 17 
 18 
Figure 3.2.3.1-20 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3 19

According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of M -Plane messages 21 
which include the following parameters (According to the M-Plane specification): 22 
grouping static-prach-configuration  23 
• leaf pattern-period - "Period after which static PRACH patterns are repeated. Unit: number of 24 
frames." 25 
• leaf guard-tone-low-re - "Number of REs occupied by the low guard tones." 26 
• leaf num-prach-re - "Number of contiguous PRBs per data section description“ 27 
• leaf guard-tone-high-re - "Number of REs occupied by the high guard tones.“ 28 
• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 29 
'single PRACH symbol’” 30 
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 31 
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max -prach-patterns“ 32 
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 33 
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 34 
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 35 
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 36 
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 37 
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 38 
PRB and the start of the lowest frequency RE belonging to the PRACH occasion.  The re -39 
offset is configured as number of PRACH REs. 40

this scenario class). 24

B. Test Entrance Criteria 33 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 34 
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O -RU. It is assumed 35 
that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O -RU is enough to validate the test. TER 36 
shall generate M-Plane messages according to one of the PRACH formats in table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose 37 
the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 “PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141 -1 or 38 
according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-RU implements this feature. If more formats are 39 
claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time, preference will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 40 
TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O-RU manufacturer will support at least one in that table. For the case of long 41 
preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since this is the only one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 42

C. Test Methodology 44 
  45 
a: Initial Conditions 46 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-47 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 48 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger s ignal from 49 
the CUSM-E.   50 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 51 
PRACH signals. 52 
b: Procedure 53 
• Set signal generator power by the following method: 54 
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-55 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 127 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 1 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  2 
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 3 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 4 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 5 
 6 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 7 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 8 
=-19.5dBm.  9 
• Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 10 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 11 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 12 
• Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 13 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions. That is at least 10 occasions.  14 
• TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 15 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 16 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tol erance in 17 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 18 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 19 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 20 
• Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 21 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number  22 
  23 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  24 
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100% determined across the minimum amount of at 25 
least 10 occasions.. 26

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for O-RAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section:  6 
• It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 7 
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 8 
 9 
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 10 
 11 
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   12 
 13 
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 14 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 15 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 16 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 17 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 18 
 19 
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 20 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  21 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 22 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 23 
 24 
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 25 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 26 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  27 
 28 
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  29 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141-1) with 30 
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-1. 31 
 32 
Figure 3.2.3.2-1 E-TM1.1 FDD 20 MHz 100RB 33 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-34 
RU DUT. 35 
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521 -1) and 36 
power levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 10MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown 37 
in Figure 3.2.3.2-2. 38 
 39 
Figure 3.2.3.2-2 UL RMC FDD 20 MHz 100 RB 40 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-41 
RU DUT. 42

 131 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
• For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  2 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD in [19] (Section 4.9.2 3 
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS138.141-1) as 4 
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 5 
MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported subcarrier spacing and the 6 
highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 7 
  8 
o Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 and Annex A 9 
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 10 
levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as described in  section 3.2.1.1.  The test 11 
numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth, if supported. 12 
Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest bandwidth supported by the O -RU 13 
DUT. 14 
  15 
• The O-RU DUT must: 16 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document. 17 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  18 
o have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal analyzer. 19 
Likewise, it must have at least two conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors to be connected to a signal 20 
generator. 21 
o be fully calibrated up to the antenna ports or (TAB connectors) (if needed). It is expected to be calibrated 22 
by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  23 
 24 
 25 
• The TER must: 26 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 27 
waveforms. 28 
o be able to calculate or extract beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) between antenna ports or 29 
TAB connectors. Alternatively, and if the O-RU DUT manufacturer provides the list of beam directions 30 
supported by the O-RU DUT, TER might calculate or extract the beam direction instead of the 31 
beamweights. 32 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) at 33 
the antenna ports or TAB connectors.  34 
o be fully calibrated up to the interfaces where is connected to the O-RU DUT antenna ports (or TAB 35 
connectors). For that, a known test signal might be either injected by the TER into the O -RU DUT, or 36 
internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog 37 
beamweights to the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane 38 
and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.   39 
 40 
 41 
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 42 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 43 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 44 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 45 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 46 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 47 
 48 
• The TER might have less testing ports than the O-RU DUT conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) if 49 
testing is carried out sequentially; or as many antenna ports as the number of conducted antenna ports (or TAB 50 
connectors) under test if testing is carried out simultaneously. 51 
 52 
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beamweights (or magnitude and phase relation) between the 53 
antenna ports or TAB connectors, or the beam direction / properties, in order to match it with the 54 
manufacturer’s declaration. 55 
 56 
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 57 
 58 
• It applies to the O-RAN CUS Specification [2]: 59 
o Clause 7.4 60

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 7 
A. Test Description and Applicability 8 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 9 
 10 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 11 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 12 
 13 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 14 
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 15 
antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O -RU DUT 16 
is operating with no beamforming.  17 
 18 
C. Test Methodology 19 
 20 
a. Initial Conditions 21 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 22 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  23 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 24 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  25 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 26 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 27 
transmitted signal.  28 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  29 
 30 
b. Procedure 31 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 32 
emulator.   33 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 34 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 35 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  36 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 37 
windows described in section3.2.1.1.1.   38 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 39 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 40 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 41 
signal. 42 
 43 
 44 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  45 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 46 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 47 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 48 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 49 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 50 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 51 
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  52 
 53 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 54 
A. Test Description and Applicability 55 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 133 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 2 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 3 
 4 
 5 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6 
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between antenna 7 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O -RU DUT is 8 
operating with no beamforming.  9 
 10 
C. Test Methodology 11 
 12 
a. Initial Conditions 13 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 14 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 15 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 16 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  17 
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 18 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 19 
signal.  20 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   21 
 22 
b. Procedure 23 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  24 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 25 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 26 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 27 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming). 28 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 29 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-30 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 31 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 32 
also triggering the signal source.   33 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 34 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 35 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 36 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 37 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 38 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 39 
the correct beam direction. 40 
 41 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  42 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 43 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 44 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 45 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 46 
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 47 
 48

beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 54 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 55 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 56

c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 41

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 1 
Beamforming 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 6 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  7 
 8 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measureme nt, see below. The 9 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 10 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 11 
beam direction. 12 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] clause 12.4.2.2: 13 
 14 
 15 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 16 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 17 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 18 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 19 
(θ). 20 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 21 
(θ). 22 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 23 
(θ). 24 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 25 
(θ). 26 
 27 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  28 
 29 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 30 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 31 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 32 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  33 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 34 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 35 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 36 
e. Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either Beamspace compression method 37 
applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler or Beamspace compression method applied to the 38 
beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa..  39 
 40 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 41 
be measured. 42 
 43 
 44 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 45 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 46 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 47 
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 48 
characteristics. 49 
 50 
C. Test Methodology 51 
 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 54 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 55 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 56 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    57

signal. 19

radio category (i.e., EVM). 23

contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 25

connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 27 
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  28

b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 6 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 7 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 8 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).    9 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 10 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 11 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 12 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 13 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 14 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 15 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 16 
also triggering the signal source.   17 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 18 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 19 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 20 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 21 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 22 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 23 
correct beam direction. 24 
 25 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  26 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 27 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 28 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 29 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 30 
declaration of the beam under test. 31 
 32 
 33 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 34 
Beamforming 35 
A. Test Description and Applicability 36 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 37 
 38 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed -based dynamic 39 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  40 
 41 
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for  the O-RU DUT to be 42 
O-RAN conformant.   43 
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 44 
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angl es, 45 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 46 
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 47 
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 48 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in  [2] clause 12.4.2.2. 49 
 50 
 51 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 52 
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 53 
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 54 
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 55 
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported eleva tion angle 56 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 139 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 1 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 2 
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 3 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for thi s specific beam direction. 4 
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 5 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  6 
 7 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 8 
configurations will be measured. 9 
 10 
 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 13 
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 14 
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  15 
 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 20 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  21 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 22 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   23 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 24 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 25 
transmitted signal.  26 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   27 
 28 
b. Procedure 29 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 30 
emulator.   31 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 32 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 33 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 34 
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 35 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 36 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 37 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 38 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   39 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 40 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 41 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from th e measured 42 
signal. 43 
 44 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  45 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 46 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 47 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 48 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 49 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 50 
connectors, or the extracted beam properties, should match the expected beam properties corresponding to the 51 
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  52

The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 1 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 2 
 3 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 4 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 5 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 6 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement .  The measured 7 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 8 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 9 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 10 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 11 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 12 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  13 
 14 
 15 
Figure 3.2.3.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 16 
 17 
a. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 18 
antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated 19 
channel estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀. The emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, 20 
with rank not lower than the number of spatial streams, and it shall not be a block -diagonal channel. As an 21 
example, a Butler channel model could be implemented as emulated channel. The O-RU will calculate and 22 
apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜  [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the 23 
users is the same as the generated in the O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming 24 
weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   25 
 26 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 27 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports o r TAB connectors 28 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
 32 
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 33 
connected to a signal analyzer. 34

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights 8 
Beamforming  9 
A. Test Description and Applicability 10 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 11 
 12 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with flexible weight -based 13 
dynamic beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC) using section extension 11.  14 
 15 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 16 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 17 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 18 
beam direction. 19 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] clause 12.4.2.2: 20 
 21 
 22 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights Beamforming 23 
conformance test should evaluate any two of following beams (called henceforth Beam1 and Beam2) for the O -RU 24 
to comply: 25 
1. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 26 
angle (θ). 27 
2. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 28 
angle (θ). 29 
3. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevati on 30 
angle (θ). 31 
4. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 32 
angle (θ). 33 
 34 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights Beamforming 35 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 36 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 37 
1. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  38 
2. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 39 
3. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 40 
4. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 41 
5. Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, eithe r BBeamspace compression 42 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler or Beamspace compression method applied 43 
to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa..  44 
 45 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 46 
be measured. 47 
 48 
 49 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 50 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 51 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 52 
connectors for each supported beam. Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 53 
characteristics. 54

a. Initial Conditions 1 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 2 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 3 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 4 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    5 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 6 
and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 7 
transmitted signal.  8 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   9 
 10 
b. Procedure 11 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   12 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 13 
and the beam under test. Every slot should be described by one section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section 14 
type 1 and will contain section extension extType=0x0B to convey the beam weights for Beam1 and Beam2.  15 
The fields in Section Extension 11 should contain the following values: 16 
disableBFWs RAD numBundPrb bfwCompHdr 
0 0 floor(allocPRBsymbol /2) (depends on method)

Where allocPRBsymbol is the number of allocated PRBs per symbol for the TM1.1 test waveform under a 24 
certain Bandwidth and Subcarrier spacing configuration. For example, for a TM1.1 with 100MHz bandwidth 25 
and 30KHz subcarrier spacing, the allocPRBsymbol is 273. 26 
If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used 27 
for this test. 28 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 29 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   30 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 31 
and decode the test frame. 32 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 33 
signal. 34

contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 40

connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 42 
corresponding to the beams under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer. 43

C. Test Methodology 8 
 9 
a. Initial Conditions 10 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 11 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  12 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 13 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   14 
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 15 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 16 
signal.  17 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   18 
 19 
b. Procedure 20 
 21 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  22 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beam weights, or equivalently 23 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 24 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elemen ts under test. For 25 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   26 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 27 
and the beam under test. Every slot should be described by one section (UL-SCH) using section type 1 28 
messages and will contain section extension extType=0x0B to convey the beam weights.  29 
The fields in Section Extension 11 should contain the following values: 30 
disableBFWs RAD numBundPrb bfwCompHdr 
0 0 floor(allocPRBsymbol /2) (depends on method) 
 31 
 32 
 33 
 34 
 35 
Where allocPRBsymbol is the number of allocated PRBs per symbol for the TM1.1 test waveform under a 36 
certain Bandwidth and Subcarrier spacing configuration. For example, for a TM1.1 with 100MHz 37 
bandwidth and 30KHz subcarrier spacing, the allocPRBsymbol is 273. 38 
If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used 39 
for this test. 40 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 41 
also triggering the signal source.   42 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 43 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 44 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or ph ase relation between 45 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O -RU. For example, 46 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 47 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 48 
correct beam direction. 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  51 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 52 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 53

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Layer nulling Beamforming 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 8 
 9 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 10 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO) with section extension 14. 11 
 12 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 13 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 14 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 15 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 16 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 17 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 18 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 19 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Layer nulling Beamforming conformance test 20 
should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel Emulation 21 
capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  22 
 23 
 24 
 25 
a. The conformance test will contain two test runs where in each of the test runs, the O -DU will indicate to 26 
the O-RU that one of the users/layers to be null at a time. For example, first test run will indicate only UE 27 
0 Layer 0 to be null (i.e. null eAxC 0) while the second test run will indicate only UE 1 layer 0 to be null 28 
(i.e. null eAxC 1), see figure Figure 3.2.3.2-4. 29 
 30 
 31 
 32 
Figure 3.2.3.2-4 Layer Nulling Beamforming Tests 33

antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages using section 36

C. Test Methodology 18 
 19 
a. Initial Conditions 20 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 21 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  22 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 23 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   24 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 25 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 26 
transmitted signal.  27 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   28 
 29 
b. Procedure 30 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 31 
emulator.   32 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 33 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH and 34 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. Section type 5 messages will contain section extension 14 35 
indicating the nulling of the eAxC to be nulled under this test run. No section type zero messages will be 36 
used for this test. 37 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 38 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 39 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 40 
to emulate the channel under test.   41 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 42 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 43 
f. Repeat procedure a. to e. for the other eAxC to be nulled (i.e. the remining eAxC not tested yet).  44 
 45 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  46 
1. For each of the test runs, the expected signal (i.e. the expected User containing non-nulled eAxC data) is 47 
measured by the signal analyzer and should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio 48 
category (i.e., EVM) 49 
2. For each of the test runs, the non-expected signal (i.e. the non-expected User containing nulled eAxC data) 50 
should be measured but no data should be detected (or heavily attenuated) by the signal analyzer.  51 
3. For each of the test runs, the expected test frame to be received for each test run by the signal analyzer should 52 
be the same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original 53 
PN23 data. 54

For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 1 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 2 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 3 
The two beams share the spectrum equally and the transmitted beam directions for UE-based and beam-ID-based 4 
beamforming are either sufficiently separated in space or a guard band can be signaled in between to avoid 5 
interference. On each beam, i.e. the beam signaled via beam ID and the beam signaled via UE -ID the testcase 6 
emulates a change of the numerology.  7

ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the UE ID based beam is the same as the generated in the O-DU. It is 21

C. Test Methodology 2 
 3 
a. Initial Conditions 4 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 5 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  6 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 7 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   8 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 9 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 10 
transmitted signal.  11 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   12 
 13 
b. Procedure 14 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 15 
emulator.   16 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 17 
and the scenario under test. Due to the symbol duration dependency on the subcarrier spacing, the section 18 
corresponding to 15 kHz SCS covers 2 OFDMA symbols duration, the section corresponding to 30 kHz 19 
SCS covers 4 OFDMA symbols and the section corresponding to 60 kHz SCS covers 8 OFDMA symbol 20 
duration to have a common measurement time of 1 ms for each numerology.   21 
c. The C-Plane message schedules two sections separated in the frequency domain at the same time, the 22 
channel bandwidth is divided in two sections of equal size. A guard band between the two frequency 23 
sections can be configured. One section presents beam ID based beamforming and the simultaneous section 24 
presents the UE ID based beamforming.  25 
d. The O-DU emulator signals section type 1 corresponding to beam ID specific beamforming for the 26 
measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols and 30 kHz SCS. The user plane data is a new PN23 27 
sequence. After the measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols, the O -DU emulator signals section type 28 
3 with mixed numerology and schedules an SCS of 15 kHz. The scheduling and measurement duration is 2 29 
OFDMA symbols. The user plane data is a new PN23 sequence. The beam ID value is the same in section 30 
type 1 and section type 3 and the occupied bandwidth for both numerologies should match as much as 31 
possible.  32 
e. The O-DU emulator signals section type 5 corresponding to the UE ID based beamforming for the 33 
measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols and 30 kHz SCS. The user plane data is a new PN23 34 
sequence. After the measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols, the O-DU emulator signals section type 35 
5 with section extension 15 mixed numerology and schedules an SCS of 60 kHz. The scheduling and 36 
measurement duration is 8 OFDMA symbols. The user plane data is a new PN23 sequence. The UE ID 37 
value is different for the section type 5 and section type 5 with section extension 15 case, emulating a 38 
situation of time domain beamforming to two separate UE IDs. The occupied bandwidth for both 39 
consecutive UE ID beams should match as much as possible.  40 
f. The O-DU emulator may schedule after the two scheduling periods of 1 ms each (4 OFDMA symbols 41 
followed by 2 OFDMA for 15 kHz SCS / 8 OFDMA symbols for 60 kHz SCS) another two sections with 42 
30 kHz SCS and section type 1 / section type 5 scheduling, see Figure 3.2.3.2-6 43 
g. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. As described, there will be 4 user plane data section, each 44 
one containing a new PN23 sequence. 45 
h. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 46 
to receive the two beams generated by the DUT.   47 
i. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the sig nal analyzer and allow it to 48 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 49

A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive properly a basic 3GPP test frame with bit masking 16 
signaling an antenna mapping for channel-information-based beamforming in uplink direction. 17 
 18 
The O-DU emulator shall signal antenna port combinations via section extension type 16 as declared by the 19 
manufacturer. An uplink signal is fed into the O-RU antenna ports signaled as belonging to the antenna mapping 20 
and the received signal should indicate good reception by analysis of EVM and PN pattern matching. In a second 21 
analysis, the uplink signal is fed into the O-RU antenna ports that are not signaled as belonging to the antenna 22 
mapping and the received signal quality, e.g. EVM should be much worse compared to the proper reception case. 23 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – bit masking for antenna mapping in Channel-24 
Information-based Beamforming should evaluate the following scenarios for the O -RU to comply and will rely on 25 
TER capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-7.  26

 6

• The TER may contain a channel emulation stage or a switch matrix to allow the proper connection of the 11

C. Test Methodology 17 
 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 20 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  21 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 22 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   23 
• Connect the signal generator to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario 24 
under test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 25 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  26 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   27 
 28 
b. Procedure 29 
a. The uplink signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the 30 
power that is about 30 dB higher as the minimum sensitivity. The data content is a new PN23 sequence in 31 
each of the two test steps. 32 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 33 
and the scenario under test.  34 
c. The O-DU emulator signals via section extension type 16 without section extension 10 the antenna masking 35 
dependent on manufacturer declaration. The antenna elements belonging to the signaled antenna mask are 36 
identified by the first eAxC value in section extension type 16.  37 
d. Test step 1: The signal generator uplink signal containing a new PN23 sequence in the FRC G -FR1-A1-5 is 38 
connected to the antenna port identified as the first eAxC value corresponding to the situation where  the 39

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 1 
Validate the correct implementation and interpretation of mandatory and optional IQ data compression formats 2 
described in [2]. Also, evaluate the consistency in U-Plane signaling. 3 
It applies to the O-RAN CUS Specification [2]: 4 
• Clause 7.4 5 
• Clause 7.5.2.10 6 
• Clause 8.3.3.13 7 
• Clause 8.3.3.15/16/17 8 
• Clause 8.3.2 9 
• Clause 8.3.3 10 
• Table 10.2-1 11 
• Annex A 12 
• Annex A.6 13 
 14 
 15 
The objective is primarily to test the protocol, prior to the compression algorithms performance.  16 
Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  17 
• U-Plane IQ data field  18 
• C-Plane udCompHdr (per clause 7.5.2.10 of [2]) 19 
• U-Plane udComphdr (per clause 8.3.3.13of [2]) 20 
• U-Plane udCompParam (per clause 8.3.3.15of [2]) 21 
 22 
Compression: The current specification [2] includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed 23 
point).  Tests should cover each one of these modes   24 
• fixed-point 25 
• block floating-point 26 
• block scaling 27 
• mu-law 28 
• modulation compression (modulation compression not included in this document) 29 
• Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 30 
• Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 31 
 32 
IQ Bit Width: IQ information can be represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests 33 
should be performed on a subset of bit widths  34 
• 9 bits 35 
• 14 bits  36 
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 37 
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 38 
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  39 
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 40 
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a test frame with uncompressed IQ (fixed 41 
16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference between 42 
measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 43 
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-44 
RU.  45 
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U-46 
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  47 
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of t hese common test methodologies.  48
