3.2.3.3.1.1 Test Frame 1 
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “ NR-FR1-CMP-TST-2 
FRAME-DL” Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL” Uplink Standard 3 
Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the description in section 3.2.1.1.5 with specific attributes 4 
described below. 5 
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 6 
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL test frame.  7 
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-8 
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 9 
Signalling and IQ information will be based on various compression schemes  10

3.2.3.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  3 
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame will include 3 4 
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 5 
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRB s are 6 
also valid.  Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 7 
•    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 8 
• -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 9 
• -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2)  10 
 11

individual PN23 sequence that will be measured and compared by the test apparatus.   8

To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 10 
(256 QAM modulation for downlink).  An example measurement is show in Figure 3.2.3.3-2. 11

3.2.3.3.1.5 Summary of Required Measurements for Compression Tests 14 
3 measurements types will be required for downlink tests and 4 measurements will be required for uplink tests.  15 
• Power level:  Using the test frames (NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL and NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL) 16 
sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, power level measurements are performed to 17 
validate compression algorithms influence on Exponent (udCompParam).  18 
The Power level measurements are called: 19 
 20 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 21 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 22 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 23 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 24 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 25 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 26 
 27 
For the test to pass, the difference between measurements should be within an acceptable range, called 28 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 = ± 1dB 29 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 = ± 1dB 30 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 = ± 1dB 31 
o  32 
• EVM:  Using a common test frame sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, EVM 33 
measurements comparisons between uncompressed IQ and compressed IQ will help validate acceptable 34 
compression influence on signal quality.  35 
 36 
These 6 EVM measurements required: 37 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 38 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0  in % 39 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 40 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 164 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 1 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 2 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 3 
 4 
For the test to pass, the difference between the compressed and uncompressed measurements for the same 5 
PDSCH signal must be within the following range: 6 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 ≤ 4 percentage points 7 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 ≤ 4 percentage points 8 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 ≤ 4 percentage points 9 
 10

be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  25

3.2.3.3.1.7 Results Analysis 2 
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 3 
conditions are met: 4 
• Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5 
• EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  6 
• Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 7

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Fixed-Point (FP)  3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 5 
format. 6 
 7 
The purpose of this test is to: 8 
• Validate correct encoding of IQ data under the following conditions.  9 
o RU Static compression configurations 10 
o Fixed point IQ data format 11 
o Selection of 2 supported bit width: 9 bits, 14 bits  12 
o Uplink / downlink 13 
• Validate that in the U-Plane PRB header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are 14 
not present  15 
 16 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 17 
 The test uses the setup and methodology described in section 3.2.1.1. 18 
 19 
 20 
C. Test Methodology 21 
a.  Initial Conditions 22 
• The O-RU is started 23 
• Fronthaul Ethernet interface configured for communication between TER and the DUT. 24 
• O-RU synchronized with TER using S-Plane 25 
• Communication established between TER and the DUT such that it is possible to exchange U-Plane and 26 
C-Plane messages  27 
• Signal Analyzer connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF output configuration  28 
• Signal Source connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF input configuration 29 
 30 
b.  Procedure 31 
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed:  32 
  33 
1. Downlink test 34 
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 35 
downlink configured as follows: no compression, (16 bits) 36 
• Arm Signal Analyzer to capture the next Frame  37 
• Send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus file to the 38 
DUT 39 
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  40 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 41 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 42 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 43 
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  44 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 45 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 46 
• CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 47 
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  48 
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  49 
• CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  50

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Modulation-10

A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 13 
format. 14 
 15 
This modulation compression format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some important 16 
differences 17 
• The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 18 
used in the Section Extension Type = 4 and Section Extension Type 5  19 
• When high level modulation is supported by the Device Under Test (DUT), Section Extension Type 5 20 
messages will be tested on the current compression test frame , tha t includes Mixed MCS test cases where 21 
high MCS user data REs and low MCS DMRS signaling data REs are in the same PRB.  22 
• The test will only verify DL correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression model is 23 
not applicable for uplink 24 
• As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 25 
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit width.  26

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 3 
This section describes conformance test cases for O-RU Delay Management. 4 
The test setup for these test cases is shown in 2.1.  5 
When performing the conformance test cases for scenario class Delay Management it does not matter which timing 6 
method is used. The different timing methods are described in clause 4.4.3, 4.4.4, 4.4.5 and 4.4.6 of [2] 7 
Delay Management downlink tests will test whether the O-RU can accurately transmit data when C and U plane 8 
messages are received at the extreme ends of their respective reception windows. Uplink tests will test whether the O-9 
RU can accurately transmit received data to the CUSM-E when the CUSM-E transmits uplink C-Plane messages within 10 
the correct uplink reception window.  It also tests whether the O-RU sends its U-Plane messages within the correct 11 
reception window. 12 
Figure 3.2.3.4-1 shows a simplified timing relation for the C- and U-Plane messages for downlink. 13 
The size of the control plane reception window on the O-RU will be: (T2a_max_up +Tcp_adv_dl) – (T2a_min_up 14 
+Tcp_adv_dl) = C-Plane reception window.   The start-point (before t=0) will be: T2a_max_up + Tcp_adv_dl = start of 15 
C-Plane transmission window. 16 
The size of the reception window for the user plane will be: T2a_max_up - T2a_min_up. The start-point (before t=0) 17 
will be T2a_max_up. 18 
As an example, if the values are set such as T2a_max_up = 264 µs, Tcp_adv_dl = 63 µs and T2a_min_up = 53 µs, then 19 
the C-Plane reception window would be 211 µs, the start of C-plane transmission window would be 327 us, the U-plane 20 
reception window would 211 µs and the start of U-plane transmission window would be 264 µs. 21

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #1: Downlink – Positive testing 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
This test case will validate that the timing on the air interface is according to requirements specified in the 5 
CUS Specification when the C-Plane and the U-Plane messages are received within the O-RU’s reception 6 
windows. 7 
 8 
Four different test cases for downlink can be performed when the expected outcome is positive, i.e. the O-RU 9 
shall be able to transmit the received U-Plane-data on the air interface.  These are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-5.  10 
Note that in these tests the C-Plane reception window may be applicable to the slot or symbol boundaries 11 
depending on the Radio’s capabilities.  That is, in some radios, the C-Plane reception window is at the 12 
beginning of each slot and all C-Plane messages will be sent at once within this window.  Other radios will 13 
require C-Plane messages to be sent in a reception window for each symbol, In all cases U-Plane messages 14 
will be sent during reception windows corresponding to each symbol regardless of whether the radio has large 15 
enough buffers to store U-Plane data for multiple symbols. 16

B. Test Entrance Criteria 8 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.  The 9 
reception windows will be calculated and used by the CUSM-E based on the delay parameters reported by the 10 
radio on the M-Plane. 11 
 12 
C. Test Methodology 13 
 14 
a. Initial Conditions 15 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 16 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. Connect the RF Signal 17 
Analyzer to the O-RU antenna port. Determine the correct reception windows the radio claims to 18 
support using delay management parameters repowered by the radio, 19 
b. Procedure 20 
Configure the CUSM-ECUSM-E to send C-Plane and U-Plane messages so these messages are received 21 
within the reception windows for respective plane according to the three cases (1..3) described in Figure 22 
3.2.3.4-5 above. NOTE: Make sure that the C-Plane message is received at least Tcp_adv_dl earlier then 23 
the corresponding U-Plane message(s) by the O-RU. 24 
 25 
On the RF-signal-analyzer observe the received signal and compare the decoded data on the selected 26 
test symbol to the send PN23 sequence for that symbol. 27 
 28 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 29 
The test passes if the received data matches the transmitted data. 30

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #2: Uplink – Positive testing 32 
A. Purpose and Description  33 
This test is MANDATORY. 34 
 35 
This test case will validate that the transmission of the U-Plane data in uplink direction are transmitted correctly by 36 
the O-RU within its transmission window.  The CUSM-E will send C-Plane messages at both ends of the C-Plane 37 
reception window specified by the radio using the M-Plane (Two tests).  The C-Plane messages will describe a test 38 
frame as shown above.  The frame will have one designated symbol in each slot (not containing DMRS 39 
information).  The C-Plane message will ask the radio to send that symbol’s data from each slot. 40 
 41 
After the correct C-Plane messages are sent the CUSM-E will trigger the signal generator to send a valid test signal 42 
to the radio’s RF port.  This signal will contain a new, known PN23 sequence in the same symbol (per slot) 43 
designated by the C-Plane messages. 44 
 45 
The positive test outcome for these uplink test cases is that the corresponding U-Plane data for a specific C-Plane 46 
message is transmitted within the O-RU’s transmission window IF the C-Plane message was received within the O-47 
RU’s reception window as shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-6 48 
.  The data will be transmitted to the radio by an external signal generator and the uplink signal will be as described 49 
above.  The test data sent by the signal generator will contain a known, new PN23 sequence in one symbol of each 50 
slot.  The CUSM-E will expect to receive the same data for the correct symbol in each slot. 51

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Transport (TRN) 15 
This test is for future study. 16 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) 17 
The purpose of this section is to specify LAA test cases to test the compliance of the O-RU to the O-RAN 18 
specifications. Although in LAA operation, regular C-Plane and U-Plane messages (used for operation over licensed 19 
spectrum as well) are transmitted over the fronthaul interface between the O -DU and O-RU, there exist additional C-20 
Plane messages that are required specifically for LAA operation over unlicensed spectrum. These additional C-Plane 21 
messages are based on Section type 7 and are communicated in both UL and DL directions between the O -DU and O-22 
RU.  23 
 24 
The LAA test cases only focus on LAA-related messages and operations. Other testing aspects that are applicable to 25 
LAA and non-LAA technologies (e.g., delay management, beamforming, compression, etc.) are not considered in this 26 
section; Please refer to other sections in the conformance test specification document. 27 
 28 
LAA considered in this section is based on 3GPP Rel. 13, which only considers downlink transmission on the 29 
unlicensed spectrum (i.e., uplink transmission goes on the licensed component carrier). Hence, all the t est cases in this 30 
section will consider downlink operation only. This includes DL U-Plane messages and DL/UL C-Plane messages. 31 
Note also that UL C-Plane messages only exist in LAA technology. 32 
 33 
The LAA test cases for the O-RU test if the O-RU is capable of conforming with the CUSM-E instructions in terms of: 34 
1) Correctly performing the listen-before-talk (LBT) procedure (i.e., managing the congestion window). 35 
2) Timely data transmission based on the spectrum sensing outcome. 36 
3) Timely deferring from occupying the spectrum based on the messages received from the O-DU. 37 
 38 
On the other hand, testing O-RU capabilities (e.g., spectrum sensing) is out of scope of this specifications since it’s not  39 
directly related to the O-RAN fronthaul interface.  40 
 41 
 CU-DU-LAA-CWM Test #1: LBT PDSCH Configuration and Response  42 
A. Test Description and Applicability 43 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  The test must be executed if the O-RU supports LAA. 44 
This test validates that the O-RU is capable of the following functions 45 
• Correctly receiving and interpreting C-Plane messages (Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 0) 46 
from the TER to correctly perform LBT.  47 
• Correctly receiving U-Plane data from the TER and correctly processes the data (i.e., drop it or transmit 48 
it) based on the LBT outcome.  49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 192 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
• Correctly performing LBT and correctly generating C-Plane messages to inform the TER about the LBT 1 
outcomes using Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 2. 2 
 3 
This test assumes that the O-RU is capable of processing Section Type 1 C-plane messages and its corresponding 4 
U-plane messages. 5 
It applies to the O-RAN CUS Specification [2]: 6 
• Clause 7.4 7 
• Clause 7.5.3.14 8 
• Clause 7.5.3.15 9 
• Clause 7.5.3.16 10 
• Clause 7.5.3.17 11 
• Clause 7.5.3.18 12 
• Clause 7.5.3.19 13 
• Clause 7.5.3.20 14 
• Clause 7.5.3.21 15 
• Clause 7.5.3.22 16 
• Clause 7.5.3.23 17 
• Clause 7.5.3.25 18 
• Clause 7.5.3.27 19 
• Table 10.2-1 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to: 22 
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages by correctly performing LBT.  23 
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly construct the UL C-Plane message as specified in Section Type 7, 24 
laaMsgType 2 with the following specialized fields. Specifically,  25 
o Verify the laaMsgLen based on the message content. 26 
o Verify that the lbtHandle parameter in the DL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 0 matches the 27 
corresponding lbtHandle parameter in the UL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 2.  28 
o Verify the lbtPdschRes parameter value. Set: {0, 1, 2, 3}. 29 
o Verify the inParSF parameter value. Set: {0, 1} 30 
o Verify the sfStatus parameter value. Set: {0, 1}.  31 
o Verify the sfnSf value.  32 
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret U-Plane data received from the TER. 33 
• Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages received from the TER.  34 
 35 
 36 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 37 
• The O-RU must support LAA 38 
• The O-RU has passed M-Plane conformance and S-Plane conformance testing. 39 
• The O-RU has antenna ports or TAB connectors for TER connections 40 
 41 
C. Test Methodology 42 
The test shall be executed by the TER issuing DL C-Plane messages to the O-RU DUT to cause the O-RU to 43 
execute LBT. Furthermore, the TER shall issue other U-Plane and C-Plane messages required for data 44 
transmission. The TER needs to emulate external interference to allow the O -RU to do LBT and send the LBT 45 
outcome to the TER based on the description in clause 7.2.5 of [2] 46 
 47 
a. Initial Conditions 48 
• TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) is initialized and configured. 49 
• The O-RU is initialized, synchronized, and configured as normal, except that it shall receive and interpret 50 
Test Commands. 51 
• The fronthaul Ethernet interface is up. 52 
•  The O-RU is running its usual software, except that it is configured to accept and execute Test 53 
Commands to enable O-RU Conformance Testing. 54 
• The TER needs to emulate the external interference (e.g., Wi-Fi, other LAA cells) for the O-RU to execute 55 
LBT.  56 
 57

description in clause 7.2.5 of [2]) such that timer expiry is a sign of test failure.  27

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LTE (LTE) 5 
This section describes applicable LTE conformance test cases for O-RAN fronthaul interface. Since there are plenty of 6 
the commonalities between the NR and LTE test cases, this section makes suitable references to the NR specific test 7 
cases sections for the LTE scenarios whenever possible, as below.   8 
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM) described in clause 3.2.3.2 9 
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) described in clause 3.2.3.3 10 
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) described in clause 3.2.3.4 11 
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) described in clause 3.2.3.6 12 
• LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Section Type 3 described in clause 3.2.3.8 13 
 14 
Subsequently, LTE-only specific generic test cases are explicitly covered in the subsections below.  One of the key 15 
differences applicable for LTE specific test cases as compared to NR is due to the explicit precoding behavior supported 16 
by some of the transmission modes for LTE.  17 
In particular, for a Category B O-RU to implement precoding for LTE TM2-TM4, specific C-Plane instructions need to 18 
be provided to the O-RU from the O-DU.  This specific aspect of the O-RAN fronthaul interface is enabled by the 19 
section extension = 0x3 described in the CUS Plane specification [2]. 20 
For all the test cases described in this section: 21

30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as shown in Figure 3.2.3.7-2. 28

The purpose of this test is to validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity 1

36.104) and power Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in E-TM1.1.  This 3 
is to improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in 4 
testing receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance. The data section will be a PN23 sequence 5 
with a seed value of all ones. 6 
 7 
Under those conditions, 3GPP compliant O-RU should deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches with 8 
the uplink signal.  9 
 10 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, 11 
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. The TER will capture the U-12 
Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the uplink signal.   13

This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios. 15

• Clause 7.4 18 
• Clause 8.3.2 19 
• Clause 8.3.3 20

 26 
a. Initial Conditions 27

which will be used for the reMask test. 39 
• The data in this section must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the 40

type zero messages will be used for this test. 42

section IDs in a single C-Plane message describing symbol #6.  45 
• The startSymbolId in the application header will be symbol #6.  46 
• The C-Plane message will have one section with the reMask set to only the odd number resource 47 
elements.  The number of PRBs will be 5. The start PRB will be 1. 48 
• The corresponding U-Plane message will be a new PN23 Sequence (initial seed is all ones) in PRBs 1 49 
through 5 of symbol #6. 50

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 20 
This section will specify the test scenarios to validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages with section type 3. 21 
The required test setup is shown in 2.1, where only a stimulus RF signal is applied. 22 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class ST3 Test #1: NR PRACH 23 
A. Test Description and Applicability {MANDATORY} 24 
This test is MANDATORY. 25 
This test will validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages containing section type 3 in 5G NR scenario by 26 
testing the correct detection of a PRACH signal.  27 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141 -1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 28 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 29 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 30 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3, at each occasion the time offset of the 31 
same preamble index (selected according to table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up 32 
to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub -frames. 33 
The scheme is repeated every frame. 34 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 202 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
 2 
Figure 3.2.3.8-1 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3 3 
 4 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of C-Plane messages 5 
with section type 3. By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the 6 
presence of the corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd 7 
according to the definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  8 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 9 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the su b-section C 10 
of this scenario class). 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 13 
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O -RU. To test 14 
the correct interpretation of section type 3, it is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters 15 
supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate C-Plane messages according to one of the 16 
PRACH formats in table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer 17 
declaration item D.103 “PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained 18 
by the M-plane in case O-RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to 19 
reduce the test time, preference will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the 20 
O-RU manufacturer will support at least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is 21 
always supported since the only one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141.  22 
C. Test Methodology 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
The O-RU is synchronized using G.8275.1. The signal generator is connected to the antenna port under test and 25 
synchronized to the same frequency reference of the O-RU. CUSM-E has completed the activation of one carrier on 26 
the O-RU port and enabled one endpoint supporting section type 3. The endpoint is configured with no data 27 
compression.  28 
b. Procedure 29 
1. Set signal generator power by the following method: 30 
d. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -31 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 32 
e. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 33 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1and38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  34

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
f. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 1 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 2 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 3 
 4 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 5 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 6 
=-19.5dBm.  7 
2. Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over frequency 8 
according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according to what TER 9 
has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 10 
3. Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times to 11 
generate a statistically significant number of SRS occasions. That is at least 10 occasions.  12 
4. Configure CUSM-E to generate C-Plane section type 3 messages according to the PRACH occasions 13 
described in subsection A and by the following approach: 14 
a. In case of a PRACH format not including preamble repetitions, only one C-Plane message with one 15 
section ID is generated per PRACH occasion. O-DU emulator will set “cpLength” field according to 16 
table 6.3.3.1-2 or table 6.3.3.1-1 TS 38.211 and to the format specified in clause 7.5.2.14 of [2].  The 17 
“timeOffset” field will be set according to the PRACH occasion position inside the slot and by 18 
following the format value specified clause 7.5.2.12of [2].  19 
b. In case of a PRACH format with preamble repetitions, the implementation can be achieved by one C-20 
Plane message with one section ID or by N number of C-Plane messages with one section ID 21 
corresponding to the single PRACH repetition as described in clause 7.2.3 of [2]. TER shall exercise 22 
both approaches and perform them in two separate test sessions by repeating steps 4 and 5. 23 
c. In both scenarios “filterIndex” field is setup based on the PRACH format and according to Table 24 
7.5.2.3-1 of [2] and “beamId” field will set to 0 (no beamforming). 25 
5. TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the exp ected 26 
preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading generator are not present the 27 
time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in table 8.4.1.1 -1 for AWGN case 28 
according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter of successful detections is 29 
incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the 30 
number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 31 
6. Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 32 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number in section type 3.  33 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 34 
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100% determined across the minimum amount of at least 10 35 
occasions. 36

3.2.4 FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA Signal Tests 13 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG) 14 
The generic tests for FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.3 FR1 FDD 15 
Conducted-Signal Tests.  Only the setup for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and 16 
conductive mode testing.  17 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  18 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for O-RAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 19 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 20 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O -DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 21 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  22 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section:  23 
• It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 24 
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not. 25 
 26 
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 27 
 28 
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   29 
 30 
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames are 31 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 32 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 33 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 34 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 35 
 36 
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames 37 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  38 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 39 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 40 
 41 
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 42 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 43 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  44 
 45 
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  46 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 47 
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.4.2-1. 48

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 28 
B. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 32 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 33 
 34 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 35 
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 36 
beamforming.  37 
 38 
C. Test Methodology 39 
 40 
a. Initial Conditions 41 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 42 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  43 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  44 
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 45 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 46 
signal. 47 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 48 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 49 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  50 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  51 
 52 
b. Procedure 53 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 54 
emulator.   55 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 56 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 57 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 208 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 1 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2.   2 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 3 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 4 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a s ingle measurement, 5 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 6 
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 7 
beam scanning. 8 
 9 
 10 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  11 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 12 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  13 
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 14 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  15 
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s wer e measured (i.e. best EVM, 16 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 17 
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  18

A. Test Description and Applicability 21 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 22 
 23 
 24

C. Test Methodology 33 
 34 
a. Initial Conditions 35 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 36 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  37 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  38

b. Procedure 46 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  47 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 48 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 49 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 50 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL -51 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 52 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2 while 53 
also triggering the signal source.   54 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 55 
plane messages to the O-DU. 56 
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 57 
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction. 58

© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 209 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 1 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 2 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing 3 
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 4 
 5

described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  8

power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 10 
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11

by extracting the beam direction. 21

2. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 31 
3. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  32 
4. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 33 
5. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  34 
 35

e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single 14 
measurement, i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from 15 
multiple angles, by for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from 16 
multiple measurement, i.e. beam scanning. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 20 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 21 
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 22 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 23 
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 24 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 25 
defined by the manufacturer.  26

b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 1

into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 13 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing 14 
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 15

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 24 
Beamforming 25 
A. Test Description and Applicability 26 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 27 
 28 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight -based dynamic 29 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  30 
 31 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 32 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction is defined 33 
by extracting the beam direction. 34 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined in clause 12.4.2.2 of [2]. 35 
 36 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 37 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 38 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 39 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 40 
(θ). 41 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 42 
(θ). 43 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 44 
(θ). 45 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 46 
(θ). 47 
 48 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam ang les will be measured. 49 
 50 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 51 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 52 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 53 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  54 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 55 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit scaler. 56 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 57

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 15 
Beamforming 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 18 
 19 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 20 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 21 
 22 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 23 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 24 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 25 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 26 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 27 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 28 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 29 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 30 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 31 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.4.2-3.  32 
 33 
 34 
 35 
Figure 3.2.4.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability antennas representing multiple UEs 36

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
 1 
b. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 2 
antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an channel 3 
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎ1
1, . . . , ℎ1
𝑀, ℎ2
1, . . . , ℎ2
𝑀] ∈ ℂ2𝑥𝑀, which is the effective channel as seen by the antennas 4 
representing the multiple UEs, which are spaced sufficiently such that the O -RU can effectively equalize out 5 
the interference between the users.. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜6 
 [𝑔1
1, . . . , 𝑔1
𝑀, 𝑔2
1, . . . , 𝑔2
𝑀]  ∈ ℂ𝑀𝑥2 in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the 7 
O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 8 
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   9 
 10 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 11 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna s ports or TAB connectors 12 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 13 
 14 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15 
 16 
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 17 
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-18 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective  MU-MIMO channel. 19 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.   20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 25 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26 
• Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  27 
• Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 with sufficient separation for 28 
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the analyzer ports with any setup information needed to 29 
synch and demodulate the MU-MIMO transmitted signal 30 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 31 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 32 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  33 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   34 
 35 
b. Procedure 36 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 37 
emulator, with the data symbols for user 1 and user 2 fully overlapping in time and frequency, but with user 38 
data initialized using different seeds for the PN23 sequence.  .   39 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 40 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH and 41 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 42 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 43 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 44 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 45 
to emulate the channel under test using the 2 test antennas.   46 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 47 
demodulate and decode the test frames for the 2 users. 48 
 49

1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should satisfy a basic 3GPP 51 
signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 52 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should be the same as the 53 
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 54

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 1 
Beamforming 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel -information-based 6 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO).  7 
 8 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 9 
the uplink direction.  10 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 11 
 12 
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating sensing antennas. 13 
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O -14 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effe ctive MU-MIMO channel. 15 
• The TER equipment must have at least two probe transmitting antennas to radiate the test signals to the O -RU. 16 
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the signal generator and the probe 17 
transmitting antennas or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being 18 
emulated between the users and the O-RU.  19 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.   20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 25 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  27 
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2  with sufficient 28 
separation for effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator with any set-up information 29 
needed to transmit the signals from the 2 UEs. 30 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 31 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 32 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  33 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  34 
  35 
b. Procedure 36 
a. Build an appropriate test signals for each of the 2 users as described above in the signal sources of the TER 37 
using a different seed to initialize the PN23 data for each user. 38 
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 39 
channel under test.  40 
c. Radiate the resulting test signals over the air into the antennas of the O-RU. 41 
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 42 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 43 
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 44 
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 45 
triggering the signal source.   46 
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 47 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload for each of 48 
the users. 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  51 
The test frame received by the TER/O-DU for each of the expected User – layer - should be the same as the signal 52 
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data.  53 
 54

A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16 
 17 
The purpose of this test is to validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level 18 
definition (Section 7.2 TS 36.141) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 36.104) and 19 
power levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in E-TM1.1.  This is to improve the 20 
likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver 21 
sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  22 
 23 
Under those conditions, 3GPP compliant O-RU should deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches with the 24 
uplink signal.  25 
 26 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the signal generator which is then transmitted over 27 
the air via the test antenna, together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. The TER 28 
will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the uplink 29 
signal.  30 
 31 
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios. 32 
 33 
It applies to the O-RAN CUS Specification [2]: 34 
• Clause 7.4 35 
• Clause 8.3.2 36 
• Clause 8.3.3 37

two antennas.  TxD uses TM2 (transmission Mode 2).  For TxD, information for 2 layers are packed into a PRB for 40

configuration before RF transmission.  42

E-TM1.1 signal.   46

two probe receiving antennas to receive each individual layer. 56

A. Test Description and Applicability 1

 3

for a Category B O-RU with two antennas.  For TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing, information for 2 layers are packed 5 
into a PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU, subsequently TM3/4 based precoding is 6 
applied based on the C Plane configuration before over the air transmission.  7 
 8

E-TM1.1 signal.   11

B. Test Entrance Criteria 15 
 16 
• The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 17 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 18 
• The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 19 
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 20 
• The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation. The TER equipment must have at least 21 
two probe receiving antennas to receive each individual layer. 22 
• The TER with connections to the O-RU must be calibrated. 23 
 24 
C. Test Methodology 25 
 26 
a. Initial Conditions 27 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 28 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   29 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU TAB connectors under test and configure the analyzer with any 30 
set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  31 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  32 
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 33 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal. 34 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 35 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 36 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  37 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  38 
 39 
b. Procedure 40 
• Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  .  The data 41 
content is a PN23 sequences starting with an initial seed of ones.   42 
• The codeword -to-layer mapping follows table 6.3.3.2-1 of TS 36.211 with one codeword to two layer 43 
mapping, but does not restrict to use two codeword to two layer mapping.   44 
• Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  45 
• Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 46 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 47 
• The test configures two antenna ports.  Therefore, two beamIDs are needed.  The same beamID is used for 48 
user data and CRS REs.   49 
o For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the 50 
Antenna Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3   51 
• Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3 as defined in CUS Plane Specification 52 
[2].  53 
o codebookIndex - indices of the precoder codebook that are used for precoding 54 
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 55 
o txScheme (transmission scheme) – set to Spatial multiplexing (no CDD) 56 
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) – set to 0001 (implies 2) 57

o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  1 
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 2 
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 3 
 4 
• Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 5

• Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 7

3.2.5 FR1 TDD Conducted Signal Tests 1 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG)  2 
All TDD tests described in this section will be combined UL and DL tests (i.e., a single test frame de scribing both 3 
uplink and downlink). The default test frame used in this section is described in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  4 
There are several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If the radio does not support 5 
the numerology used in the example tests as reported in the M-plane it will be up to the test developer to modify their 6 
tests to adapt to the radio.  This can usually be accomplished by using stock test patterns described above .  The test is 7 
expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document but things like symbol numbers, number of PRBs, etc. 8 
may have to be changed. 9 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL/UL 10 
A. Test Description and Applicability 11 
This test is MANDATORY. 12 
 13 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink and downlink requirements for O-14 
RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  Subsequent tests will build on this to exercise additional capabilities of the 15 
Fronthaul. 16 
 17 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 18 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 19 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  a basic 3GPP, TDD test frame using the 22 
default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.5 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 23 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is 24 
required).  As per section 3.2.1.1.3 this test requires all-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This 25 
configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all symbols that do not c ontain PDCCH channels. 26 
 27 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 28 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 29 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1 in downlink direction and 30 
G-FR1-A1-5 (SCS30k_51RB) in the uplink direction. If the O-RU does not support this bandwidth another 3GPP 31 
FRC can be selected. In the test frame, all PDSCH data is set to all zeros and PUSCH is set to all zeros.  It will be 32 
for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 33 
 34 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 35 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.3 above. 36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer and 41 
signal source to the O-RU antenna ports and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to 42 
allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.   43 
b. Procedure 44 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 45 
emulator.  Built the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator 46 
control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. Every symbol other 47 
than the ones used in the test should either be allocated with user data or left una llocated (empty). If 48 
allocated with user data, they be described by either a single or multiple sections (DL-SCH that are used for 49 
the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for 50 
this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the 51 
O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of 52 
times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be 53 
the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD 54

transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, 1 
extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source.  2

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  5 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 6 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 7 
2. The test frame received in downlink direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described 8 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and all zero data, the test passes. 9 
3. The test frame received in uplink direction by the TER should be the same as the signal described above.  If it 10 
contains all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequence data, the test passes. 11 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O-RAN 16 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test modifies the previous test by using a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH 17 
sections. 18 
 19 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 20 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 21 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   22 
 23 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 24 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 25 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding 26 
is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a 27 
PN23 sequence. 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 31 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New 32 
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 33 
 34 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 35 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 41 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 42 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   43 
b. Procedure 44 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 45 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 46 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 47 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be 48 
described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 49 
messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane 50 
messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described 51 
in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and 52 
allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer 53 
and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is 54 
responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be 55 
compared to those sent by the signal source. 56

be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. Each symbol should be a new PN23 sequence, that is 6 
PRB 0 should contain the data from a new PN23 sequence for each symbol. Symbols number 5 and 6 7 
should be stock data sections type “E” as shown above.  This stock data section consists of two adjacent 8 
symbols each containing two sections.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain 4 section IDs in a 9 
single C-Plane message describing symbols #5 and #6.  The startSymbolId in the application header will be 10 
symbol #5. The third section ID for symbol #6 will have the SymInc bit set informing the O-RU that this 11 
section will begin describing symbol #6. The corresponding U-Plane messages will be a new PN23 12 
Sequence for each symbol (5 and 6). Additional sections should be included to describe the DCI symbols as 13 
well as Reference Signals described in 38.141-1.  14 
 15 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS30k_51RB, 100 16 
MHz) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal has a PN23 sequence as user data.  Configure the source 17 
to generate a new PN23 sequence in symbols #5 and #6.  Configure the Signal Source to play test 18 
waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger signal from the O -DU emulator 19 
that all C-Plane messages have been sent.  Ensure the O-RU and source are synchronized so downlink slots 20 
do not conflict with uplink slots.  Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Only 21 
symbols #5 and #6 in each slot will be used in this test. Symbol number 6 will be a guard symbol in the 22 
flexible slot if the TDD configuration according to table 3.2.1.1 is used, so only 2 uplink slots per frame are 23 
possible. If needed, another symbol than symbol number 6 can be selected.  All other symbols will might 24 
either contain either reference signals only or data and reference signals but will not be considered part of 25 
the test.  These two symbols will be used to determine whether the radio properly increments the current 26 
symbol ID when the SymInc bit is set. The C-Plane message for symbol #6 should have the SymInc bit set.  27 
This message should have a third section describing symbol #6 (using the SymInc mechanism).  All PRBs 28 
in each symbol will be requested (In the example waveform 51 PRBs). 29

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using reMask parameter 3GPP DL/UL – 1 
Resource Allocation 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 6 
the reMask parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in 7 
the downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with the reMask parameter set.    8 
This test uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 9 
 10 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 11 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 12 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using the reMask bit in both uplink and downlink.   13 
 14 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 15 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 16 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 17 
 18 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 20 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 21 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  22 
 23 
The radio must support the reMask Parameter as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the 24 
ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 25 
 26 
C. Test Methodology 27 
a. Initial Conditions 28 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 29 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 30 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 31 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 32 
described below. 33 
b. Procedure 34 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 35 
emulator and modified as described below. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared 36 
channel.  Build the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) as described below for the signal source. Use the 37 
CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and 38 
downlink signals. Every symbol other than the ones used in the test should either be allocated with user 39 
data or left unallocated (empty). If allocated with user data, they will be described by either a single or 40 
multiple sections (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No 41 
section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U -Plane messages for 42 
downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 43 
3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 44 
demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source 45 
to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for 46 
receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those 47 
sent by the signal source. 48 
 49 
For the downlink slots and symbols:  50 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 51 
signal as described below. If the symbols other than the ones under test (symbol #2) have user data 52 
allocated, these Every symbols should be described by a single or multiple type 1 sections (DL-SCH 53 
and DCI).   Only symbol #2 will be used for the reMask test. The data in this section must be a PN23 54 
sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the PN23 will be in PRB1 and continue in 55 
consecutive resource elements to the end of PRB5. No section type zero messages will be used for this 56 
test.  The PN23 sequence will be interleaved with DMRS signals as shown below:  57

 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation – 25 
Coupling C and U plane via time and frequency 26 
A. Test Description and Applicability 27 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 28 
 29 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O-RAN 30 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test uses time and frequency to couple C-Plane and U-Plane messages. 31 
 32 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 33 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 34 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   35 
 36 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 37 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 38 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding 39 
is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a 40 
PN23 sequence. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via time and 41 
frequency. 42 
 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 45 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New 46 
Radio only. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via time and 47 
frequency. 48 
 49 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 50 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 51

 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Coupling C and U plane via 33 
Time and Frequency and Section Description Priorities 34 
A. Test Description and Applicability 35 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 36 
 37 
The purpose of this test is to test whether the radio can implement coupling U and C plane via time and frequency 38 
and section description priorities requirements for O-RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test combines the 39 
FDD, uplink and downlink tests for these same features.  Note, there are two versions of this feature: coupling C 40 
and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities and coupling C and U plane 41 
messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities (optimized).  This test requires both tests to be 42 
performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise only one test is to be performed in the radio only supports 43 
one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test methodology below. 44 
 45 
Starting with the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 46

including all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 22

that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 24 
declaration of the beam under test.  The procedures for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class 25 
Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) and test case 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario 26 
Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) should be used. 27 
5. These expected results are applicable for either or both forms of this test. 28 
6. If all of the above results are observed the test passes. 29
