 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Static SRS Allocation UL – Resource Allocation 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16 
 17 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 18 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for TDD.  The O -RU must report through the M-Plane 19 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 20 
 21 
This test will use the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.  The test will have the CUSM emulator 22 
configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency resources reserved for static uplink 23 
SRS, these will be limited to the uplink slots of the TDD frame.  The signal source will be programmed to send 24 
simulated SRS signals in a subset of those resources.  The O-RU should receive this SRS signals and pass them 25 
through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from the 26 
CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB above Reference 27 
Sensitivity power Level described in TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the likelihood that all data will 28 
be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver sensitivity but only the O -RAN 29 
protocol compliance.  The placement of the time frequency resources is not specified in this test so it may be placed 30 
in any uplink slots of the TDD frame. 31 
 32 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 33 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 34 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that the signal received by the CUSM emulator 35 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 36 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physical 37 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 38 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chan ce of false 39 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 40 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O -RU. 41 
 42 
 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 45 
supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth.  46 
It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors . Note 47 
this signal may be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in 3GPP TS 138.141 -1 if the radio does not 48 
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if 49 
the radio supports that numerology and bandwidth.  50 
 51 
C. Test Methodology 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-54 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 55 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 56 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 57 
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 58

generate a statistically significant number of SRS occasions. That is at least 10 occasions. 15 
• Extract IQ information  16 
• Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 17 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation.  18 
 19 
 20 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  21 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8% as median EVM measured over the minimum 22 
number of SRS occasions of at least 10 occasions. 23 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 24

A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 32 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for downlink slots.  The O -RU must report through 33 
the M-Plane that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat the spirit of test 3.2.3.8.1 34 
(5GNR  PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-35 
Plane. 36 
 37 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141-1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 38 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 39 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 40 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 configuration index 132 (From Table 41 
6.3.3.2-3, unpaired spectrum), at each occasion the time offset of the same preamble index (selected according to 42 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each 43 
PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The scheme is repeated every frame. The test 44 
must be conducted using a PRACH format and configuration index the ra dio has reported it supports 45

The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 4

this scenario class). 6 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 7 
resources reserved for static uplink PRACH.  The default is the PRACH configuration described in 3GPP above, but the 8 
test may be conducted with changes if the radio does not support those exact configurations.  The signal source will be 9 
programmed to send simulated PRACH signals in those resources.  The O -RU should receive this PRACH signal and 10 
pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from 11 
the CUSM emulator and the O-RU. 12

B. Test Entrance Criteria 15

By the M-plane or by manufacturer declaration, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier 17 
bandwidths by the O-RU. It is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O -18

table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 20 
“PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-21 
RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to redu ce the test time, preference 22 
will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O -RU manufacturer will support at 23 
least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since this is the only 24 
one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 25

C. Test Methodology 27 
  28 
a: Initial Conditions 29 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-30 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 31 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 32 
the CUSM-E.   33 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 34 
PRACH signals. 35 
b: Procedure 36 
• Set signal generator power by the following method: 37 
g. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -38 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 39 
h. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 40 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  41 
i. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 42 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 43 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 44 
 45 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 46 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 47 
=-19.5dBm.  48 
• Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 49 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 50 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 51 
• Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator.  Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 52 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions.  That is at least 10 occasions. 53 
start

• TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 1 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 2 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in 3 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 4 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 5 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 6 
• Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 7 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number  8

 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using section extension 13 for frequency 15 
hopping UL/DL – Resource Allocation 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 18 
 19 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of the O-RU to correctly interpret section extension 13, 20 
frequency hopping, for the uplink.  Note, since frequency hopping is only used in uplink in 5G NR this test will be   21 
limited to the uplink slots of the basic TDD signal. 22 
 23 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 24 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 25 
downlink and uplink of the specified signal using section extension 13 for the uplink.  The downlink portion of the 26 
test is not part of this test and may be any signal or no downlink signal at all.  27 
 28 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non -contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 29 
(48 of the 51 in the uplink slots) or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio 30 
supports will be used in this test. 31 
 32 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 33 
(No precoding is required). 34 
 35 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 36 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 37 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 38 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  39 
 40 
The radio must support section extension 13 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 41 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 42

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  46 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for O-RAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 47 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 48 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O -DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 49 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  50 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 51 
• It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 52 
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 53 
 54 
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 55

 3

• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 5

 10 
a. Initial Conditions 11 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 12 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  13 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence betw een the antenna 14

• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 16 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 17 
transmitted signal.   18

 20 
b. Procedure 21 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   22

signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL-SCH 24 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 25 
resources in the test waveform. 26

signal. 32

3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 40 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 41

• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 3 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  4 
• Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 5 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 6 
signal.  7 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   8 
 9 
b. Procedure 10 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  11 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 12 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 13 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test . For 14 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).  15 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 16 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-17 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. 18 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 19 
also triggering the signal source.   20 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 21 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 22 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 23 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 24 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 25 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 26 
the correct beam direction. 27 
 28 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  29 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 30 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 31 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 32 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 33 
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 34 
 35 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 36 
Beamforming 37 
A. Test Description and Applicability 38 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 39 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined -beams 40 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 41 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 42 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 43 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 44 
beam direction. 45 
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” an d/or “beam 46 
groups”, as defined in clause 12.4.2.2 of [2]. 47 
 48 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 49 
 50 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 51 
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 52 
 53 
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  54 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O -DU 55 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 56

1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 1 
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  2 
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  3 
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 4 
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  5 
 6 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 7 
 8 
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  9 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 10 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 11 
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 12 
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  13 
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  14 
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 15 
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  16 
 17 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  18 
 19 
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  20 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 21 
the test should include the following beams: 22 
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 23 
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 24 
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 25 
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 26 
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 27 
 28 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 29

B. Test Entrance Criteria 32 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 33 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics.  34

C. Test Methodology 36 
 37 
a. Initial Conditions 38 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 39 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  40 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 41 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   42 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 43 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 44 
transmitted signal.  45 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 46 
   47 
b. Procedure 48 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   49 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 50 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL -SCH and 51 
DCI) using section type 1 messages.   52 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 53 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   54 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 55 
and decode the test frame. 56

signal. 2

1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 5 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 6 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 7 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 8 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 9

corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11

beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  17 
 18 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 19 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 20

beam direction. 22 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined in clause 12.4.2.2 of [2]. 23 
 24

 28

b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 30 
angle (θ). 31 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 32 
(θ). 33 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 34 
(θ). 35 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 36 
(θ). 37 
 38

 40 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 41 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 42 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 43 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  44 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14 -bit mantissa. 45 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 46 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 47 
e. . Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either  Beamspace compression 48 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. or Beamspace compression method 49 
applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa 50 
 51

be measured. 53

C. Test Methodology 6 
 7 
a. Initial Conditions 8 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 9

 17 
b. Procedure 18 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   19 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 20 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 21 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 22 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 23 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 24 
should be 0x0.  25 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 26 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   27 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 28 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 29 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 30 
signal. 31

plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 52 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or magnitude and phase 53 
relation between all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O -RU. For 54 
example, repeating the process for a number of different sets of beamweights will simulate the reception of 55 
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the 56 
sensitivity to the correct beam properties. 57

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  2 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 3 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 4 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 5 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 6 
declaration of the beam under test. 7

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 9 
Beamforming 10 
A. Test Description and Applicability 11 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 12 
 13 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 14 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 15 
 16 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either differe nt or same channel 17 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 18 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 19 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 20 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 21 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 22 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 23 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 24 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 25 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.5.2-2.  26 
 27 
 28 
Figure 3.2.5.2-2 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 29

ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated channel estimate 32

B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
 11 
• The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 12 
connected to a signal analyzer. 13 
• The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O -RU antenna ports and the signal 14 
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 15 
O-RU and the users.  16 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 17 
connected to each TRX chain.  18 
 19 
C. Test Methodology 20 
 21 
a. Initial Conditions 22 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 23 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  24 
• Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 25 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   26 
• Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 27 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 28 
transmitted signal.  29 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   30 
 31 
b. Procedure 32 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   33 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 34 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL -SCH and 35 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages.  36 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 37 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 38 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 39 
to emulate the channel under test.   40 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 41 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 42 
 43 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  44 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 45 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 46 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 47 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 48

Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  1 
• U-Plane IQ data field  2 
• C-Plane udCompHdr (clause 7.5.2.10 of [2]) 3 
• U-Plane udComphdr (clause 8.3.3.13 of [2]) 4 
• U-Plane udCompParam (clause 8.3.3.15 of [2]) 5 
• Modulation compression parameters used in the Section Extension Type =4 6 
• csf (constellation shift flag)  7 
• modCompScaler (modulation compression scaler value) 8 
 9 
Compression: Current specification includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed point).  Tests 10 
should cover each one of these modes   11 
• fixed-point 12 
• block floating-point 13 
• block scaling 14 
• mu-law 15 
• modulation compression 16 
• Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 17 
• Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 18 
 19 
IQ Bit Width: For fixed-point, block floating point, block scaling and mu-law compression, IQ information can be 20 
represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests should be performed on a subset of bit 21 
widths  22 
• 9 bits 23 
• 14 bits  24 
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 25 
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 26 
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  27 
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 28 
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a TDD test frame with uncompressed IQ 29 
(fixed 16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference 30 
between measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 31 
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-32 
RU.  33 
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U -34 
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  35 
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of these common test methodologies.  36 
3.2.5.3.1.1 Test Frame 37 
TDD test methodology for compression will combine similar downlink and uplink test patterns used for FDD test. The 38 
main difference is that uplink and downlink tests are performed simultaneously for TDD .  39 
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “ NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-40 
TST-DL” TDD Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL” TDD Uplink 41 
Standard Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the description in section 3.2.1.1.3 For scenario #3 42 
(Conducted TDD Tests for FR1 Radios) with specific attributes described below. 43 
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 44 
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-DL test frame.  45 
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-46 
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 47

3.2.5.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  3 
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame will include 3 4 
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 5 
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRBs are 6 
also valid.  Figure 3.2.5.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 7 
•    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 8 
• -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 9 
• -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2)  10 
 11

 17 
For the data integrity test to pass, the comparison between stimulus payload and the measured payload should 18 
be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  19

• Presence/Absence of U-Plane Header measurements (uplink only): to validate that in the U-Plane PRB 21

3.2.5.3.1.7 Results Analysis 1 
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 2 
conditions are met: 3 
• Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  4 
• EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5 
• Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 6 
• Uplink U-Plane Header measurements exclude fields for static compression 7 
 8

 TDD UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Fixed-Point 3 
(FP)  4 
A. Test Description and Applicability 5 
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 6 
 7 
The purpose of this test is to: 8 
• Validate correct encoding of IQ data under the following conditions.  9 
o RU Static compression configurations 10 
o Fixed point IQ data format 11 
o Selection of 2 supported bit width: 9 bits, 14 bits  12 
o Uplink / downlink 13 
• Validate that in the U-Plane PRB header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are 14 
not present  15 
 16 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 17 
The test uses the setup and methodology described in section 3.2.5.3.1. 18 
 19 
 20 
C. Test Methodology 21 
a.  Initial Conditions 22 
• The O-RU is started 23 
• Fronthaul Ethernet interface configured for communication between TER and the DUT. 24 
• O-RU synchronized with TER using S-Plane 25 
• Communication established between TER and the DUT such that it is possible to exchange U -Plane and 26 
C-Plane messages  27 
• Signal Analyzer connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF output conf iguration 28 
• Signal Source connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF input configuration  29 
 30 
b.  Procedure 31 
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed:  32 
  33 
1. Launch Uncompressed Test  34 
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the downlink 35 
and uplink configured as follows: no compression, (16 bits) 36 
• Arm Signal Analyzers and Signal Source 37 
o Arm Signal analyzer to capture the next Frame  38 
o Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 39 
• Arm the CUSM emulator to send the TDD O-RAN test frame, including 40 
o Downlink: CU-plane of “uncompressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus 41 
file to the DUT 42 
o Uplink: C-plane of “uncompressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-UNC-16B test stimulus file 43 
to the DUT 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 282 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
• ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 1 
• Launch the test until: 2 
o RF Signal Analyzer has captured the downlink frame 3 
o CUSM-E has captured the uplink U_plane data  4 
2. Uncompressed Downlink Measurements  5 
• With the RF Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  6 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 7 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 8 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL PDSCH2 in dBm 9 
• With the RF Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  10 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 11 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 in % 12 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 in % 13 
• With the RF Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  14 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  15 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  16 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 17 
3. Uncompressed Uplink Measurements  18 
• Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace of the CUSM-E 19 
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  20 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 21 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 22 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 23 
 24 
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  25 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 in % 26 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 in % 27 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 in % 28 
 29 
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform Data integrity measurements  30 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  31 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  32 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2 33 
4. Launch “compressed” Test  34 
• Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the downlink 35 
and uplink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits) 36 
• Arm Signal Analyzers and Signal Sources 37 
o Arm Signal analyzer to capture the next Frame  38 
o Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 39 
• Arm the CUSM emulator to send the TDD O-RAN test frame, including 40 
o Downlink: CU-plane of the “Compressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) 41 
test stimulus file to the DUT 42 
o Uplink: CU-plane of the “Compressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test 43 
stimulus file to the DUT 44 
• ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 45 
• Launch the test until: 46 
o RF Signal Analyzer has captured the downlink frame 47 
o CUSM-E has captured the uplink U_plane data 48 
5. Compressed Downlink Measurements  49 
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  50 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 51 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 52 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 53 
• With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  54 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 55 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 in % 56 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 in % 57 
• With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  58 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  59 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  60

o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 1 
6. Validate Downlink conformance conditions  2 
• Power measurements within acceptable range  3 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-4 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 5 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-6 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 7 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-8 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 9 
• EVM measurements within acceptable range  10 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-11 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 12 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-13 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 14 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-15 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 16

o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0 =0 18

o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 =0 20

o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1 =0 22 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 =0 23 
7. Compressed Uplink Measurements  24

• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  26 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 27 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 28 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 29 
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  30 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 in % 31 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 in % 32 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 in % 33 
• Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  34 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  35 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  36 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2 37 
8. Validate Uplink conformance conditions  38 
• Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  39 
o U-Plane udComphdr (clause 8.3.3.13 of [2]) 40 
o U-Plane udCompParam (clause 8.3.3.15 of [2]) 41 
• Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  42 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-43 
Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 44 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-45 
Measured-Power-UL_PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 46 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-47 
Measured-Power-UL PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 48 
• Validate EVM measurements within acceptable range  49 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-50 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 51 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-52 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 53 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-54 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 55 
• Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  56 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0 = 0 57

 TDD UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Non-Static (NS) Fixed-Point (FPF)  3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4

3.2.6 FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA Signal Tests 1 
 2 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG)  3 
All TDD tests described in this section will be combined UL and DL tests (i.e., a sin gle test frame describing 4 
bothuplink anddownlink). The default test frame used in this section is described in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document 5 
for FR1 radios and Section 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 radios.  6 
There are several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If the radio does not support 7 
the numerology used in the example tests as reported in the M-plane it will be up to the test developer to modify their 8 
tests to adapt to the radio.  This can usually be accomplished by us ing stock test patterns described above.  The test is 9 
expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document but things like symbol numbers, number of PRBs, etc. 10 
may have to be changed. 11 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL/UL 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink and downlink requirements for O -16 
RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  Subsequent tests will build on this to exercise additional capabi lities of the 17 
Fronthaul. 18 
 19 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2, the O -DU emulator 20 
(i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that 21 
require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink and uplink the default signal.   22 
 23 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  a basic 3GPP, TDD test frame using the 24 
default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.5 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 25 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is 26 
required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a PN23 27 
sequence. 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 of this document.  31 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-32 
TM1.1 for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described by TM FR2 -TM1.1 for 33 
FR2.  It will be for 5G New Radio only.  34 
 35 
 36 
C. Test Methodology 37 
a. Initial Conditions 38 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 39 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer and 40 
signal source to the O-RU antenna ports and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to 41 
allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.   42 
b. Procedure 43 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 44 
3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 in the CUSM emulator.  Built the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for the signal 45 
source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe 46 
the signal. Every symbol used in the test should be described by a single section (DL -SCH that are used for 47 
the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be u sed for 48 
this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the 49 
O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2.  Repeat the 50 
entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and 51 
decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate 52 
downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 295 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the 1 
signal source. 2 
 3 
 4 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  5 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal pe rformance requirement for 6 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 7 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer shall be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains all 8 
the same PRB assignments and  the PN23 sequence, the test passes. 9 
 10 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is MANDATORY. 13 
 14 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O -RAN 15 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test modifies the previous test by using a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH 16 
sections. 17 
 18 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O -DU emulator 19 
(i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that 20 
require the O-RU to transmit on thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   21 
 22 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 23 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document (or a similar 3GPP  24 
waveform) except only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and 25 
Category B radios (No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all 26 
uplink user data will also be a PN23 sequence. 27 
 28 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 29 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document.  30 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM -FR1-31 
TM1.1 for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described by TM FR2 -TM1.1 for 32 
FR2.  It will be for 5G New Radio only.  33 
 34 
 35 
C. Test Methodology 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 38 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 39 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 40 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   41 
b. Procedure 42 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 43 
3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 in the CUSM emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared 44 
channel.  Build the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator 45 
control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. 46 
Every symbol used in the test should be described by a single section (DL -SCH that are used for the test, 47 
DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  48 
Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU 49 
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2.  Repeat the entire 50 
frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the 51 
test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and 52 
uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane 53 
messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source.  54

 1 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-2 
SCH and DCI) except symbols #5 and #6 which will be used for the SymInc test. The data in these sections 3 
must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. Each symbol should be a new PN23 sequence, 4 
that is PRB 0 should contain the data from a new PN23 sequence for each symbol. Symbols number 5 and  5 
6 should be stock data sections type “E” as shown above.  This stock data section consists of two adjacent 6 
symbols each containing two sections.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain 4 section IDs in a 7 
single C-Plane message describing symbols #5 and #6.  The startSymbolId in the application header will be 8 
symbol #5. The second section ID for symbol #5 will have the SymInc bit set informing the O -RU that the 9 
next section will begin describing symbol #6. The corresponding U-Plane messages will be a new PN23 10 
sequence for each symbol (5 and 6). Symbol #6 contains PTRS in TM FR2-TM1.1. The data payload 11 
should be mapped around the PTRS.  Additional sections should be included to describe the DCI symbols 12 
as well as Reference Signals described in 38.141-1.  13 
 14 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform  on the RF Signal Source.  Note this 15 
signal has a PN23 sequence as user data.  Configure the source to generate a new PN23 sequence in 16 
symbols #5 and #6.  Configure the Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting 17 
when it receives a trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that all C-Plane messages have been sent.  Ensure 18 
the O-RU and source are synchronized so downlink slots do not conflict with uplink slots.  Load C -Plane 19 
message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Only symbols #5 and #6 in each slot will be used in 20 
this test. All other symbols will contain either reference signals or data but will not be considered part of 21 
the test.  These two symbols will be used to determine whether the radio properly increments the current 22 
symbol ID when the SymInc bit is set. The C-Plane message for symbol #5 should have the SymInc bit set.  23 
This message should have a second section describing symbol #6 (using the SymInc mechanism).  All 24 
PRBs in each symbol will be requested (In the example waveform 51 PRBs).  25 
 26 
Steps: 27 
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  28 
• Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 29 
source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  30 
• Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 31 
3.2.1.1.4  for FR2.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal 32 
analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the frame. 33 
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 34 
Antenna port  35 
• Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 36 
• Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots 37 
• Extract Payload for both signals 38 
• Compare payload binary sequences  39

requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 46

respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 4 
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the 5

extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source.  8

this radio category (i.e., EVM). 47

 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation – 1 
Coupling C and U plane via time and frequency 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O-RAN 6 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test uses time and frequency to couple C-Plane and U-Plane messages. 7 
 8 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O-DU emulator 9 
(i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that 10 
require the O-RU to transmit on thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   11 
 12 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 13 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 14 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding 15 
is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a 16 
PN23 sequence. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via time and 17 
frequency. 18 
 19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document.  21 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-22 
TM1.1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described by TM FR2 -TM1.1 for FR2.  It will 23 
be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via 24 
time and frequency. 25 
 26 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 27 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 32 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 33 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 34 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   35 
b. Procedure 36 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 37 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 38 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 39 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be 40 
described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 41 
messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane 42 
messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described 43 
in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and 44 
allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer 45 
and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is 46 
responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be 47 
compared to those sent by the signal source.  All section IDs in C-Plane messages and downlink U-Plane 48 
messages must be 4095. 49 
 50 
C-Plane and Downlink U-Plane messages sent by the TER will have valid values in the following fields: 51 
• EAxC ID 52 
• Datadirection bit  53 
• Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 54 
• SectionID must have a value 4095 55 
• SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 305 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
It is the responsibility of the TER to properly arrange uplink U-Plane messages using only time and 1 
frequency resources. 2 
 3 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  4 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 5 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 6 
2. All received U-Plane messages must have section ID equal to 4095 7 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 8 
all the same PRB assignments and all zero data, the test passes. 9

 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Coupling C and U plane via 11 
Time and Frequency and Section Description Priorities 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to test whether the radio can implement coupling U and C plane via time and frequency 16 
and section description priorities requirements for O-RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test combines the 17 
FDD, uplink and downlink tests for these same features.  Note, there are two versions of this feature: coupling C 18 
and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities and coupling C an d U plane 19 
messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities (optimized).  This test requires both tests to be 20 
performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise only one test is to be performed in the radio only supports 21 
one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test methodology below. 22 
 23 
Starting with the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3  for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O-DU 24 
emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages 25 
that require the O-RU to transmit on thedownlink and uplink the signals described below.   26 
 27 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 28 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 29 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 30 
 31 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 32 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document 33 
and those specified below.  The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as 34 
described by TM-FR1-TM1.1 for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described by 35 
TM FR2-TM1.1 for FR2.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) 36 
or TAB connectors.  It will be a TDD signal. 37 
 38 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 39 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 40 
 41 
C. Test Methodology 42 
a. Initial Conditions 43 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 44 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 45 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 46 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   47 
b. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities  48 
Build an appropriate C and U plane signals for the signals described below in the CUSM emulator. Every 49 
slot used in the test should be described by a single C-Plane message with multiple sections (DL-SCH that 50 
are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using a section type 1 message. No section type zero messages will 51 
be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those 52 
messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame 53 
the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test 54 
frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and 55 
uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U -Plane 56 
messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source.  57

including all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 7 
4. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 8 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 9 
declaration of the beam under test.  The procedures for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class 10 
Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) and test case 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario 11 
Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) should be used. 12 
5. These expected results are applicable for either or both forms of this test. 13 
6. If all of the above results are observed the test passes. 14

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using Non-contiguous PRB Allocation 16 
Section Extension using section extension 12 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 19 
 20 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 21 
section extension 12, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the 22 
downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with section extension 12.    This test 23 
uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 24 
 25 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O-DU emulator 26

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Static SRS Allocation UL – Resource Allocation 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 5 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for TDD.  The O-RU must report through the M-Plane 6 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 7 
 8 
This test will use the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2.  The test 9 
will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency resources 10 
reserved for static uplink SRS, these will be limited to the uplink slots of the TDD frame.  The signal source will be 11 
programmed to send simulated SRS signals in a subset of those resource s.  The O-RU should receive this SRS 12 
signals and pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane 13 
messages sent from the CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB 14 
above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the 15 
likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver 16 
sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  The placement of the time frequency resources is not 17 
specified in this test so it may be placed in any uplink slots of the TDD frame.  18 
 19 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 20 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 21 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that the signal received by the CUSM emulator 22 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 23 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physical 24 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 25 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chance of false 26 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 27 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O -RU. 28 
 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 of this document.  32 
The O-RU must indicate is supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing 33 
and 100 MHz Bandwidth for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth for FR2.  It will be 34 
for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors . Note this signal 35 
may be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in 3GPP TS 138.141 -1 if the radio does not support the 36 
numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the radio 37 
supports that numerology and bandwidth.  38 
 39 
C. Test Methodology 40 
a. Initial Conditions 41 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-42 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 43 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 44 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 45 
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 46 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for statis 47 
SRS signals. 48 
.   49 
b. Procedure 50 
• Build an SRS signal in the signal generator that fits in the preconfigured time frequency resources set in the 51 
initial configuration. 52 
• Load the waveform into the signal source: 53 
• Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it rece ives a 54 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that signals the start of a frame boundary. 55 
• Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  56

© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
• Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port 1 
connected 2 
• TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 3 
• Start SRS waveform generation on the signal generator. Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times to 4 
generate a statistically significant number of SRS occasions. That is at least 10 occasions. 5 
• Extract IQ information  6 
• Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 7 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation.  8 
 9 
 10 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  11 
3. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8% as median EVM measured over the minimum 12 
number of SRS occasions of at least 10 occasions. 13 
4. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 14

 UC Plane O-RU Base Class TDD Test UL – Static PRACH allocation 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 22 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for downlink slots.  The O -RU must report through 23 
the M-Plane that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat the spirit of  test 3.2.3.8.1 24 
(5GNR  PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-25 
Plane. 26 
 27 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141 -1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 28 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 29 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 30 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 configuration index 132 (From Table 31 
6.3.3.2-3, unpaired spectrum), at each occasion the time offset of the same preamble index (selected according to 32 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame) . Each 33 
PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The scheme is repeated every frame. The test 34 
must be conducted using a PRACH format and configuration index the radio has reported it supports  35 
 36 
 37 
Figure 3.2.6.1-3 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3, Unpaired Spectrum, configuration index 132 38

grouping static-prach-configuration  4

• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 10 
'single PRACH symbol’” 11 
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 12 
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max -prach-patterns“ 13 
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 14 
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 15 
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 16 
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 17 
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 18 
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 19

• list occasion-parameters – “list of cp-lengths, gp-lengths and beam-ids applicable per each 22

• leaf occasion-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key in 'occasion-parameters' 25

• leaf gp-length - "Guard period length.“ 29 
• leaf beam-id  - "This parameter defines the beam pattern to be applied to the U-30

• leaf frame-number - "This parameter is an index inside the pattern-length, such that PRACH 32 
occasion is happening for SFN which fulfills following equation: [SFN mod pattern -length = 33 
frame-id]“ 34 
• leaf sub-frame-id - "Identifier of sub-frame of the PRACH occasion. Value is interpreted in 35 
the same way as subframeId field in a section description of a C-Plane message.“ 36 
• leaf time-offset - "This parameter defines the time-offset from the start of the sub-frame to 37 
the start of the first Cyclic Prefix of PRACH pattern" 38

By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the presence of the 40 
corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according to the 41

The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 43

C. Test Methodology 9 
  10 
a: Initial Conditions 11 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-12 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 13 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 14 
the CUSM-E.   15 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 16 
PRACH signals. 17 
b: Procedure 18 
• Set signal generator power by the following method: 19 
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5 -20 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 21 
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 22 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  23 
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 24 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 25 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 26 
 27 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 28 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 29 
=-19.5dBm.  30 
• Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 31 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 32 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 33 
• Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator.  Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 34 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions.  That is at least 10 occasions. 35 
• TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 36 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 37 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in 38 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 39 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 40 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time.  41 
• Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 42 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number 43 
  44 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  45 
a. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100% determined across the minimum amount of at least 46 
10 occasions.. 47
