 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using section extension 13 for frequency 1 
hopping UL/DL – Resource Allocation 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of the O-RU to correctly interpret section extension 13, 6 
frequency hopping, for the uplink.  Note, since frequency hopping is only used in uplink in 5G NR this test will be   7 
limited to the uplink slots of the basic TDD signal. 8 
 9 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O-DU emulator 10 
(i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that 11 
require the O-RU to transmit on thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using section extension 13 in just the 12 
uplink downlink.  The downlink portion of the test is not part of this test and may be any signal or no downlink 13 
signal at all. 14 
 15 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 16 
(48 of the 51 in the uplink slots) or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio 17 
supports will be used in this test. 18 
 19 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 20 
(No precoding is required).  All uplink user data will be a PN23 sequence. 21 
 22 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 23 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document.  24 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3  25 
for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2.  It will 26 
be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors.  27 
 28 
The radio must support section extension 13 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 29 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 30 
 31 
C. Test Methodology 32 
a. Initial Conditions 33 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 34 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 35 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 36 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O -RU antenna port and configure it as 37 
described below. 38 
b. Procedure 39 
Build an appropriate IQ signal as described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 in the 40 
CUSM emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build  the appropriate 41 
test frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the 42 
appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test 43 
should be described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section 44 
type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U -45 
Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 46 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal 47 
analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s 48 
signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of 49 
the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which 50 
can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 51 
 52 
 53 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Any signal may be used if needed by the TER or no downlink signal 54 
may be used. 55 
 56 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5: SCS30k_51RB for FR1 57 
or G-FR2-A3-1: SCS120k_66RB for FR2) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal should contain a new 58 
PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 50 for symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 151 for symbol 7.  59

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for O-RAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section:  6 
• It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 7 
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not.  8 
• Section 3.2.1.1.2 for scenario #2 non-conducted OTA FDD FR1 radios contains a description of test setups, as 9 
mentioned by 3GPP TS 37.843 defines various radiated test systems. If not explicitly mentioned, scenario #4 10 
non-conducted OTA TDD tests for FR1 and FR2 radios will inherit those descriptions.  11 
 12 
• It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 13 
 14 
• It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   15 
 16 
• If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames are 17 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definitio n of this Stock Test A can be 18 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 19 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 20 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 21 
 22 
• If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U -Plane test frames 23 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  24 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 25 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot.  26 
 27 
• If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 28 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 29 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  30 
 31 
• For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  32 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for TDD, based on uplink/downlink 33 
configuration 3 and special subframe configuration 8  (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 20MHz bandwidth 34 
(100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-1. 35

o FR2 TDD downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR2-TM1.1 test frame for TDD in (Section 1

described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 120KHz subcarrier spacing and 3 
100 MHz Bandwidth, or lower depending on DUT capability. If not supported, then it will use any 4 
other supported subcarrier spacing and the highest bandwidth of the O -RU DUT. 5 
o NR FR1 test models described in TS 38.141-1 are also applicable for BS type 1-O conformance testing. 6

Annex A TS 38.141-2) of the Radiated Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141-2). 10 
The O-RU manufacturer declares a minimum EIS level for the considered OTA sensitivity direction 11 
declaration. The power levels inclining from the angle of arrival that should be tested (RoAoA) is at 12 
least 30dB above the OSDD EIS Reference Sensitivity power level. The test numerology will be 13 
preferably 120kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth based on G-FR2-A1-3 in TS 38.141-2,  14 
or lower depending on DUT capability. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier spac ing and the 15 
highest bandwidth supported by the O-RU DUT. 16 
 17 
•  Radiated tests coordinate system is based on the coordinate system defined in O-RAN CUS Specification [2], 18 
clause 12.5.2. 19 
 20 
 21 
• The O-RU DUT must: 22 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.2 of this document. 23 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  24 
o be fully calibrated up to Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) as defined in 3GPP TS 38.141 -2. It is expected 25 
to be calibrated by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  26 
 27 
 28 
• The TER must: 29 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 30 
waveforms. 31 
o be able to calculate or extract the spherical beam direction via OTA measurements.  32 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beam direction at the RIB point.   33 
o be fully calibrated up to the interface where it interacts with the DUT’s RIB. For that, a known test signal 34 
might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and 35 
the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog beam forming to apply a directional characteristic to 36 
the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C -Plane and U-Plane 37 
signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.  Alternatively, calibration 38 
methods for radiated test setups that are described in 3GPP TR37.941 can be used. 39 
o    40 
 41 
 42 
• The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 43 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 44 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 45 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 46 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 47 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 48 
 49 
• The TER might have a single test antenna if a single beam direction and polarization is measured and an 50 
optional positioning method to perform directional radiation measurements sequential ly, or multiple test 51 
antennas to perform directional radiation measurements and/or polarizations at the same time.  52 
 53 
• It is up to the TER on how to extract the beam direction and beam properties at the DUT’s RIB in order to 54 
match it with the manufacturer’s declaration. 55 
 56 
• The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 57

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 8 
 9 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 10 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 11 
 12 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 13 
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 14 
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam direction in below evaluation.   15 
 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 20 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  21 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  22 
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 23 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 24 
transmitted signal. 25 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 26 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 27 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  28 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  29 
 30 
b. Procedure 31 
f. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above 32 
in the O-DU emulator.   33 
g. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 34 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 35 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  36 
h. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 37 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.   38 
i. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 39 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 40 
j. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement , 41 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 42 
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 43 
beam scanning. 44 
 45 
 46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  47 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the contemplated transmitted beam direction should satisfy a 48 
basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM).  49 
2. The test frame received at the contemplated transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the 50 
same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 51 
data. 52 
3. The extracted or measured beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. 53 
best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected transmitted beam direction for the expected no 54 
beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  55 
 56 
 57

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 6 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 7 
 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
• Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 11 
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected receive beam direction in below evaluation.   12 
  13 
 14 
C. Test Methodology 15 
 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
• Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 18 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  19 
• Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable toleranc e.  20 
• Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1. 3.2.1.1.4 and 21 
configure the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 22 
signal. 23 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 24 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 25 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  26 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range .  27 
 28 
b. Procedure 29 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  30 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 31 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array, corresponding to the 32 
manufacturers declaration of the expected receive direction. 33 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 34 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-35 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  36 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 37 
while also triggering the signal source.   38 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 39 
plane messages to the O-DU. 40 
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 41 
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  42 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 43 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 44 
of the test signal from different receive beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really 45 
focusing the sensitivity to the correct expected receive beam direction. 46 
 47 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  48 
1. The test frame received at the contemplated receive beam direction by the TER/O -DU should be the same as the 49 
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 50 
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 51 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the 52 
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  53

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 55 
Beamforming 56 
A. Test Description and Applicability 57 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 1 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  2 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 3 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted beam direction is 4 
defined by extracting the beam direction from directional measurement samples . 5 
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and/or “beam 6 
groups”, as defined in O-RAN CUS Specification [2], clause 12.4.2.2.  7 
 8 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined in O-RAN CUS Specification [2], clause 12.4.2.2.  9 
 10 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 11 
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 12 
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  13 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to  the O-DU 14 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 15 
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 16 
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  17 
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 18 
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  19 
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported el evation angle (θ). 20 
 21 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  22 
 23 
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  24 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 25 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 26 
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 27 
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  28 
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 29 
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ).  30 
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ).  31 
 32 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured.  33 
 34 
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  35 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 36 
the test should include the following beams: 37 
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 38 
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 39 
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 40 
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 41 
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 42 
 43 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 44 
 45 
 46 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 47 
• Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 48 
characteristics. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam directio n in below evaluation.   49 
 50

signal. 3 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 4 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 5 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  6 
Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range 7 
b. Procedure 8 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  9 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 10 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array, corresponding to the 11 
manufacturers declaration of the expected receive direction. 12 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 13 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL -14 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  15 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 16 
while also triggering the signal source.   17 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 18 
plane messages to the O-DU. 19 
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 20 
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction.  21 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 22 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 23 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O -RU is really focusing 24 
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 25 
 26 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  27 
1. The test frame received at the contemplated receive beam direction by the TER/O -DU should be the same as 28 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the origina l PN23 data. 29 
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 30 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under 31 
test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  32

(θ). 57

using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 40 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 41 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 42 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 43 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 44 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   45

demodulate and decode the test frame. 47

 10

see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angle s, 14 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 15

ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 17

(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  25

(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 27

e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 30 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction.  31

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 27 
Beamforming 28 
A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 32 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU -MIMO). 33 
 34 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 35 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 36 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 37 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The  measured 38 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 39 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 40 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 41 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 42 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 43 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-3.  44 
 45

antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages the channel 5

O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 10

effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator ports with any setup information needed to 49 
transmit the signals from the 2 UEs 50 
• Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4. 51 
• Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 52 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as d efined in 3.2.1.1.4.  53 
• Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  54

 1 
3.3 S-Plane Conformance Tests 2 
This section describes tests that are used to validate S-Plane functional and performance conformance of network 3 
elements using the O-RAN WG4 fronthaul interface defined in [2] and the O-RAN WG4 M-Plane interface defined in 4 
[3].  This version of the conformance specification defines both O-DU and O-RU conformance tests.  Future versions of 5 
this specification will describe additional S-Plane functional and performance conformance tests of other clocks used in 6 
the front haul, e.g. PRTC/T-GM, etc.  7 
S-Plane functionality of the O-RU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-RU using the M-Plane or SMO as 8 
appropriate, whereas, S-Plane performance is determined by over-the-air (OTA) or conductive (i.e. a cabled electrical 9 
connection to the DUT’s radio interface) measurements of O-RU synchronization signal.  10 
S-Plane functionality of the O-DU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-DU using the SMO. As M-plane 11 
specification in WG5 become available, retrieval of O-DU status based on M-plane will be considered for functional 12 
tests, as well.  13 
The performance of O-DU is determined by time/frequency error measurements on output signals (such as 1PPS, or 14 
fronthaul SyncE+PTP master ports in LLS-C1 and LLS-C2).  When applicable, O-DU tests are based on ITU-T 15 
G.8275.1 [5] profile. ITU-T G.8275.2 [10] is not specifically supported in this document version because this standard 16 
does not specify performance criteria and is left for further study.   17 
O-DU tests consider both local and remote PRTC connections, as shown in Figure 3.3.1 -1. The connection type is 18 
relevant for performance tests because the input conditions applied to DUT depends on connection types supported: 19 
•  An embedded PRTC (e.g. using embedded GNSS receiver, Figure 3.3.1-1a) has no exposed direct O-DU 20 
interface, so test stimulus is applied to the Time Reference input (e.g. GNSS RF).  21 
•  A local PRTC is collocated with the O-DU and may communicate to O-DU via either a 1PPS and serial link 22 
(e.g. ITU-T G.8271 or similar interface), Figure 3.3.1-1b, or an Ethernet interface (PTP and PLFS, Figure 23 
3.3.1-1c).  24 
• A remote PRTC is located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul) and communicates to O-DU via an 25 
Ethernet interface (PTP and PLFS, Figure 3.3.1-1d). 26 
 27 
 28 
Figure 3.3.1-1 Methods to connect PRTC to O-DU  29 
 30 
Both functional and performance tests require the provision of a test equipment i.e. provision of a test setup that 31 
includes a CUSM-E which delivers the necessary stimuli as described in section 3.3.1. 32

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
The S-Plane conformance test suite assumes that the vendor’s equipment is conformant and has been tested to meet the 1 
requirements of G.8275.1 and IEEE1588v2 and other relevant S-Plane standards. Therefore, this document does not 2 
attempt to duplicate tests for these standards.    3 
The below sections of bullets summarize the test scope in order to validate conformance to the synchronization plane 4 
specification referenced by [2] section 9.  5 
• General points which apply to testing of both functional and performance aspects of the O-DU and O-RU: 6 
• The tests apply to both 4G (LTE/E-UTRA) and 5G (NR) and are applicable to all O-RAN IOT profiles listed 7 
in Annex A 8 
• A CUSM-E is needed to generate the necessary M-plane or SMO and S-Plane traffic that includes PTP and 9 
possibly SyncE SSM over ESMC. It is synchronized to a time reference. For the O-RU testing a CUSM-E 10 
must also generate CU-Plane background traffic. 11 
• Shall be done in the lab at constant temperature  12 
• The CUS specification [2] may in the future support different kinds of Physical Layer Frequency Support 13 
(PLFS), however the only fully specified PLFS by the current edition of [2] is SyncE. Thus, these S -Plane tests 14 
are defined to include SyncE when required. 15 
• Testing of SyncE is optional and is only valid when the SyncE device which can be driven by a  master (e.g. O-16 
RU) makes use of it. Therefore, the related SyncE test cases are optional. 17 
 18 
• The following bulleted points apply specifically to functional tests of the O-RU in addition to the general points 19 
above, 20 
• For validation of S-Plane, the following are used: 21 
o A CUSM-E sends and receives synchronization information over the fronthaul interface.  22 
o A Measurement Equipment to perform frequency/phase/time measurements from any available 23 
synchronization interface.  24 
o DUT’s S-Plane reports its state over M-Plane. 25 
• The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 26 
 27 
• The following bullets points apply specifically to functional test of the O-DU in addition to the general points 28 
above: 29 
• On its input ports, O-DU end application like O-RU may optionally use SyncE along with PTP. However, in 30 
the case of an LLS-C1/C2 O-DU acting as G.8275.1 SyncE+PTP master, SyncE emission is mandatory on the 31 
fronthaul for validation of S-plane: 32 
o DUT reports its S-Plane state over SMO (and in future WG5 M-plane). 33 
• The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 34 
• The CUSM-E also provides local time source input signals to the O-DU: 35 
o GNSS RF signals, delivered by a GNSS generator referenced to the local time reference  36 
o PRTC output signals (1PPS + serial link)  37 
• The following bulleted points apply specifically to performance tests for O-RU and O-DU in addition to the general 38 
points above. 39 
• These tests are not defined to fully stress the DUT. Rather they are intended to stress the DUT enough to 40 
determine that it can properly operate via the defined front haul protocol.    41 
o The thermal profile is not defined. The tests are defined to be run at a constant temperature, but the 42 
thermal profile choice and range is left as a decision for the vendor.  43 
o The variable C/U-Plane profile (for example similar to test case 13 shown in figure VI.11 of ITU-T 44 
G.8261 [10]) will be defined as part of the work on the future performance tests.  45 
o All performance tests described in this section assume the following two components in the procedure (test 46 
methodology sections): 47 
o Establishing the necessary M-plane session to bring up the O-RU or O-DU and make it ready for 48 
transmission of a measurement signal. For the O-DU, the establishment of an M-plane session can be done 49 
when the WG5 M-plane is available. In the interim, the O-DU shall be configured using SMO.  50 
o For the O-RU in addition to the M-plane session, the transmission of a test signal necessitates the 51 
provision of a CU plane test vector. The test vector needs to have enough information to set up a 52 
synchronization channel within the radio frame transmitted over the air.  53 
o For O-DU performance tests the test cannot be executed unless the O-DU provides an Ethernet port with 54 
sync master function and/or a 1PPS output signal.  55

• The acceptance criterion for the performance tests is to satisfy the 3GPP OTA TAE limits specified in 3GPP 1 
TS 36.141 [18] for 4G (LTE) and 38.141-2 [20] for 5G (NR), and summarized in eCPRI [11] and ITU-T 2 
G.8271 [7]. The conditions applicable to each test will be set out in the relevant sections below (future work 3 
item). OTA TAE limits for MIMO/Tx Diversity is outside the scope of this document because they apply 4 
between endpoints belonging to the same O-RU. 5 
• The CUS Specification [2] which follows eCPRI and IEEE802.1 CM recommendation, defines two examples 6 
of O-RU types, but these are not strict classes like the T-BC classes specified in ITU-T G.8273.2. 7 
3.3.1 Test Environment 8 
The following describes the necessary functions and capabilities of the test equipment in order to perform O-RU or O-9 
DU conformance tests. A diagram of the O-RU test set up shown in Figure 3.3.1-2, and a similar diagram of the O-DU 10 
test set up is shown in Figure 3.3.1-3.  11 
Referring to Figure 3.3.1-2, the stimulus is applied to the O-RU via an Ethernet interface which simulates an O-RAN 12 
CUS-Plane protocols by using equipment to generate an O-DU and/or front haul time reference. This interface carries 13 
the PTP and SyncE stimulus to test the O-RU and carries M-Plane information to configure DUT and as needed C-14 
Plane and U-Plane information to generate a test signal to measure time accuracy.  Performance measurements are 15 
made at the radio output.  These measurements can be made either over the air (called a non-conductive measurement), 16 
or via a cable connection from the radio interface (called conductive measurement).  17 
Figure 3.3.1-2 applies to LLS-C1/C2/C3 topologies.  LLS-C4 topology is for further study. 18

CUSM-Plane Emulator: This function implements various planes (C, U, S, M) to simulate a front haul/transport 1 
network connecting to DUT (i.e. O-RU, O-DU). It should be capable of testing S-Plane performance under stress with 2 
various noise profiles. S-Plane signals sent to DUT and measurement equipment are traceable to reference signals 3 
received from the master time reference. Emulator should generate noise free reference signal for Measurement 4 
Equipment and (when required) a noise profile for the DUT. The CUSM -Plane emulator may be composed of multiple 5 
components or could be a single component containing all the capabilities listed below. When O -RU is the DUT UC-6 
Plane is needed for O-RU to generate a radio information required to measure timing.  For O-DU, CU-Plane 7 
functionality is not used since timing is measured directly from an Ethernet or 1PPS test port.  8 
• Time Reference/S-Plane: This equipment is the frequency and time reference. It delivers frequency (e.g. 9 
SyncE, 10MHz, 1PPS), phase (e.g.1PPS, 10ms frame boundary) and time (e.g. ToD, PTP) signals to the Sync 10 
Tester equipment and to the various simulators/generators listed below. PRTC specified by ITU-T G.8272 is 11 
one example in terms of performance. The level of performance for these reference signals should be 12 
significantly (by an order of magnitude) better than the 3GPP synchronization requirements when absolute 13 
limits are measured against the reference clock. The time reference function with the CUSM -Plane emulator is 14 
traceable to UTC. The time output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment performing 15 
time error measurements. The phase output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment 16 
performing time error measurements. 17 
• PRTC/T-GM: for testing an O-DU from either local or remote PRTC over Ethernet. It includes a PTP master 18 
clock and, when applicable, a SyncE master function that propagate the Time reference and allow adding 19 
configured noise patterns. 20 
• GNSS Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated local PRTC. The GNSS emulator will provide an RF 21 
signal to the O-DU. The RF signal emulates a signal received by a GNSS antenna and allows adding 22 
configured noise patterns. As an alternative to a GNSS emulator following case is acceptable: the test 23 
environment provides the capability to access a GNSS antenna mounted at a suitable location inside the 24 
building with line of sight to sufficient number of GNSS satellites (>4).  25 
• PRTC Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated T-GM, but without an integrated local PRTC: in this 26 
case, the test setup needs to provide the following signals to the O-DU: 1PPS (according to ITU G.703), 27 
10MHz, and serial link carrying ToD and PRTC status. There are different ToD formats such as ITU -T G.8271 28 
Annex A and NMEA. The ToD format of the test setup needs to deliver the ToD format supported by the O -29 
DU. This interface allows adding configured noise patterns. 30 
• SMO: Responsible for configuring CUSM Plane emulator to send configuration to DUT for the defined 31 
conformance tests. 32 
• M-Plane: Translate the SMO configuration into the proper M-Plane messages to correctly configure and 33 
report status from the DUT.  For O-RU testing this is implemented using WG4 M-Plane protocol.  For O-DU 34 
this is implemented by either using a Network Management System (SMO) which is compatible with the DUT 35 
or using a WG5 M-Plane emulator. 36 
• UC-Plane: S-Plane tests require the transmission of UC-Plane traffic over the fronthaul, the emulator shall 37 
implement the O-RAN UC-Plane protocol and shall send a stock data frame defined in Section 3.2.1.1.5 and 38 
shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 as UC-Plane messages to DUT O-RU. 39 
The emulator shall merge all traffic types for transmission over the fronthaul without degrading performance of S-40 
Plane. 41

Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired synchronization information from 1 
the test signal transmitted by the DUT, and then measuring this information to determine if the performance is within 2 
limits. This could be a single piece of test equipment containing all the capabilities listed below, or it may be created by 3 
interconnecting a separate signal analyzer and performance measurement system.  4 
For O-RU testing the following measurement equipment is needed. 5 
• Signal Extractor: This equipment demodulates the time reference signal from the O-RU’s downlink radio 6 
interface. It receives RF signals from the DUT over air or via coaxial interface. 7 
• Performance Measurement Equipment: This equipment performs error measurements of the timing and 8 
frequency output signals from the Signal Extractor.  It uses standard metrics to validate if the measured signal 9 
meets the defined limits.  10 
For O-DU testing the following measurement equipment is used. 11 
• PTP/SyncE/1pps Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired 12 
synchronization information from the Master PTP/SyncE Ethernet port (e.g. decoding the PTP and/or SyncE 13 
sent from DUT master port) or 1PPS output from the DUT (LLS-C3/C4 only),then measuring this information 14 
to determine if the performance of the DUT is within limits. 15 
3.3.2 Functional test of O-RU using ITU-T G.8275.1 profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3) 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This test is MANDATORY. 18 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-RU is correctly synchronizing to a CUSM Emulator delivering both 19 
PTP and (optionally) SyncE using ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile and that the O-RU correctly reports its status to the 20 
CUSM Emulator based on the nominal or degraded synchronization conditions generated by CUSM Emulator.  21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
O-RU is connected to CUSM Emulator directly.  23 
O-RU must be operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane properly (as defined in 3.2.1.1.5). 24 
C. Test Methodology 25 
a. Initial Conditions 26 
This test uses the O-RU (DUT), a CUSM-Plane emulator with SMO features to generate stimulus for the O-27 
RU (DUT) and signal analyzer to measure the radio interface timing. 28 
b. Procedure 29 
Three conditions must be tested: 30 
Startup: CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE ports in passive state (no 31 
messages sent) 32 
Nominal: CUSM-E is configured to start acting as a PTP master compliant with the ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] 33 
profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. If SyncE is to be tested 34 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU -T 35 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value as specified by ITU-T G.8275.1 [5]. 36 
Degraded: There are two levels of degraded conditions for both PTP and SyncE that can be configured to the 37 
CUSM-Emulator. 38 
• The first degradation level is where the CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE 39 
ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile, and sending configured clockClass and/or 40 
SSM values within the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane.  41 
• The second degradation level is where the same clockClass and/or SSM values are sent by CUSM -E 42 
outside the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane. 43

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00

D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 8 
The acceptance criterion is that the status reported by the O-RU for the steps defined in above procedure matches 9 
the results described in Table 3.3.2-2 for PTP only and Table 3.3.2-3 for PTP and SyncE.  The left column 10

3.3.3 Performance test of O-RU using ITU-T G.8275.1 Profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3) 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is MANDATORY.   13 
This test validates that an O-RU is synchronizing from a CUSM-plane Emulator delivering configured (ideal and 14 
normal operating conditions) PTP and (optionally) SyncE. Frequency and time error generated by the O-RU must 15 
be within specified limits.  16 
This test focuses on LLS-C1 and LLS-C2..  LLS-C3 will be addressed in a future version. 17 
CUS -plane spec lists two classes of O-DU (class A has ±15 ppb frequency error limit; class B has ±5 ppb limit). 18 
This test applies to the strictest one from O-RU prospective and therefore considers class A O-DU. 19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 343 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
O-RU is connected to CUSM-Plane Emulator via direct fiber link(s).  1 
Conformance Functional test 3.3.2 is successfully passed. 2 
It is the vendor’s responsibility to make sure that limits defined in the test are also met in worse -case field 3 
conditions.  Thermal testing, PTP PDV tolerance and SyncE jitter/wander tolerance are beyond the scope of this 4 
test. 5 
O-RU must be operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane properly. (as defined in 3.2.1.1.5) 6 
C. Test Methodology 7 
a. Initial Conditions 8 
These tests use the O-RU DUT and a CUSM-Plane emulator with SMO features.   9 
Frequency and time error are measured on the Air interface at the O-RU output.  This is accomplished by 10 
utilizing the CUSM-Plane emulator to generate the basic downlink signal according to the “UC-Plane O-RU 11 
Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL” applicable to the O-RU under test, i.e. 3.2.3.1.1,  3.2.4.1, 3.2.5.1.1, or 12 
3.2.6.1.1; and the Signal Analyzer performing the appropriate frequency and time error measurements.  13 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 14 
G.8275.1 [5] profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. 15 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU -T 16 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value.  17 
The DUT shall have achieved frequency and phase lock prior to starting the test. 18 
b. Procedure:  19 
Unlike the functional test defined in section 3.3.2, where start-up / nominal / degraded scenarios are tested, 20 
only nominal scenarios with ideal and normal operation input noise are tested in this section.  21 
1. Ideal: PTP and SyncE (if used) provide “ideal” O-RU input synchronization with no added noise. 22 
2. Normal Operation: PTP and SyncE (if used) provide “Within normal operating limits” O-RU inputs as 23 
specified in CUS-Plane Specification [2], simultaneously meeting two limits:  24 
a. Maximum time error: ± 1420 ns,  25 
b. Maximum frequency error (0.1Hz low pass filtered): ±15 ppb  26 
Notes applicable to this Normal Operation condition test: 27 
• The CUSM-Plane Emulator may be configured to generate the time and frequency error of PTP and SyncE, 28 
either simultaneously or sequence.  29 
• CU and M plane messages do not need to be modified. It has no impa ct if they are delayed by the time and 30 
frequency error applied in this test. 31 
• The time error added to the input signal shall follow a sinusoidal waveform with amplitude (A) and frequency 32 
(f). Three such signal frequencies are specified for the test, but intermediate ones can be used for testing, as 33 
long as the following relationship between amplitude and frequency: A[ns] = 15[ppb]/(2*pi*f[Hz]) is 34 
maintained and simultaneously meets the 2a and 2b conditions above. An additional constant time error may 35 
be added to the sinusoidal waveform for each frequency, so that the maximum time error reaches the 36 
maximum value of 1420 ns: cTE[ns] = 1420[ns] - A[ns]. 37 
• Based on ITU-T analysis it is considered that the time error budget comprises both constant and dynamic 38 
errors. Because of this the time error budget is proposed to be split so that the constant time error represents 39 
around half or more of the total budget. This is approximately consistent with ITU-T G8271.1 [7]. 40 
• Testing any higher frequency input noise than the ITU cut-off frequency (0.1Hz) would require using limits 41 
that are defined by vendor-specific parameters (CUS spec provides an example for a 75 MHz low pass filtering 42 
and 18ppb frequency noise generation O-RU). It is therefore outside the scope of this document and such 43 
performance must be validated by vendors and documented in test reports. 44

(3GPP limit 1500 ns – CUS spec 1420ns = 80 ns, where 1420ns is the error allocated to the O-DU for 17 
LLS-C1).   18

3.3.5 Functional test of O-DU Synchronized from ITU-T G.8275.1 profile 10 
PRTC/T-GM (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is MANDATORY. 13 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-DU is correctly synchronizing to a timing reference delivering by 14 
PTP (and optionally SyncE) when using ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile and that the O-DU correctly reports its status 15 
to the SMO or WG5 M-Plane controller based on the nominal or degraded synchronization conditions generated by 16 
CUSM Emulator.  17 
This test covers all cases where O-DU is synchronized using the Ethernet interface, whether the PRTC/T-GM is: 18 
• Local (direct link from a co-located equipment): case c in figure 3.3.1-1 19 
• Remote (network connection from a distant equipment): case d in figure 3.3.1 -1 20 
These O-DU functional tests do not consider configurations which have multiple sources. It is assumed the O -DU 21 
has only a single synchronization source. Multiple sources such as a Multiport PTP/SyncE are for further study. 22 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 23 
O-DU is connected to the sync stimuli directly as shown in Figure 3.3.1-3 via the Ethernet Test Port.  24 
O-DU must be properly operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane (when WG5 M-Plane specification is 25 
available and implemented). (as described in 3.3.1). 26 
C. Test Methodology 27 
a. Initial Conditions 28 
This test uses the O-DU (DUT), a sync tester setup and SMO features to generate stimulus for the O-DU 29 
(DUT) and retrieve its sync status. For LLS-C1/C2 the fronthaul ports must be enabled as ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] 30 
synchronization master.  31 
b. Procedure 32 
Three conditions must be tested: 33 
Startup: The CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE ports in passive state (no messages 34 
sent). 35 
Nominal: The CUSM-E is configured to start acting as either a PTP master compliant with the ITU-T 36 
G.8275.1 [5] profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. If SyncE 37 
is to be tested CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to 38 
ITU-T G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value as specified by ITU -T G.8275.1 [5]. 39 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
© 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. Your use is subject to the copyright statement on the cover page of this specification.
                                
 346 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v06.00 
Degraded: There are two levels of degraded conditions for both PTP and SyncE that the CUSM-E can be 1 
configured to. 2 
• The first degradation level is where the CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE 3 
ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile, and sending configured clockClass and/or 4 
SSM values within the O-DU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane.  5 
• The second degradation level is where the same clockClass and/or SSM values are sent by CUSM-E 6 
outside the O-DU’s configured accepted limits via the SMO (or M-plane). 7 
To cover the all the relevant PTP functional scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.5-1 steps through 8 
the Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in a sequence.  Since SyncE is optional, there are two columns, one for 9 
PTP status and a second for SyncE.   In this table each of the status items (Startup, Nominal, Degraded) 10 
correspond to the conditions defined above. 11

D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 16 
The acceptance criterion is that the status reported by the O-DU for the steps defined in above procedure 17 
matches the results described in the 2 tables which follow, Table 3.3.5-2 and Table 3.3.5-3. The tables cover 2 18 
different use cases.  1) PTP without SyncE, and 2) PTP with SyncE. The test engineer should choose the 19 
appropriate table(s) based on the equipment’s intended application(s).    20 
Each of the tables are formatted similarly.  The left two columns indicate the procedural steps as defined in 21 
Table 3.3.2-1 . The right columns list the O-DU status parameters that are defined in the M-Plane specification 22 
[3] (chapter 13 Synchronization Aspects) and relevant YANG models. These parameters are queried from the 23 
test O-DU and their values should match those listed in the tables.  24 
When an O-DU’s selected time source is PTP and optional SyncE, the parameters to be checked are: Sync-25 
state, PTP sync-source-status, PTP clock-class, SyncE sync-source-status, SyncE quality-level. 26 
In LLS-C1 and LLS-C2 and regardless of the selected time source, the PTP Master sync-source-status, PTP 27 
Master clock class, SyncE Master sync-source-status, and SyncE Master Quality Level shall also be 28 
monitored.  29 
For PTP master clock-class, optional SyncE quality-level and master quality-level, the “Rcvd Value” table 30 
entry indicates that the value read should be the same as the one received by the O -DU (except in Startup and 31 
Disconnected modes when there is no such received value and the default one is reported).  32 
In case of local failure in the O-DU then O-DU should use FREERUN mode. 33 
These tests do not consider configurations which have multiple sources. This is for further study.  34

3.3.6 Functional test of O-DU Synchronized from Embedded or Local non-PTP 1 
PRTC (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL-MANDATORY. This test is mandatory if the DUT contains: 4 
• Either an O-DU with an embedded local PRTC using a GNSS receiver (see case a in figure 3.3.1 -1) 5 
• Or an O-DU connected by a 1PPS + serial interface (e.g. ITU-T G.8271, see case b in figure 3.3.1-1) to a co-6 
located PRTC provided by the test setup. 7 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-DU is correctly synchronizing to a non-PTP local time source and 8 
that the O-DU correctly reports its status to the SMO or WG5 M-Plane controller based on the nominal or degraded 9 
synchronization conditions generated by CUSM Emulator.  10 
This O-DU functional test does not consider configurations which have multiple time sources.  11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
O-DU is connected to the time sync stimuli directly as shown in Figure 3.3.1-3 via the GNSS RF signal or local 13 
PRTC output signals.  14 
O-DU must be properly operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane (when WG5 M-Plane specification is 15 
available and implemented) emulator components. (as described in 3.3.1). 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
a. Initial Conditions 18 
This test uses a time reference, synchronization tester setup and SMO/M-Plane functions to generate stimulus 19 
for the O-DU (DUT) and then retrieves the O-DU’s sync status. For LLS-C1/C2 the fronthaul ports must be 20 
enabled as an ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] synchronization master.  21 
b. Procedure 22 
Three conditions must be tested: 23 
Startup: The CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with its output signals (either GNSS RF or PRTC ones) 24 
not started sending time information to DUT. 25 
Nominal: The CUSM-E is configured to start delivering output signals (either GNSS RF or PRTC ones) in 26 
LOCKED status with optimal time and state information.  27 
Degraded: The degraded conditions for GNSS receiver’s or PRTC output are not well defined.  There are no 28 
defined “slightly degraded” or “severely degraded” signal indications. Thus, the indication of a 29 
degraded state may be implementation specific.  Further, a degraded GNSS scenario is the only 30 
condition which causes the O-DU to lose its locked status.  31 
For GNSS RF signals, one proposal is to simulate the reception of a single satellite with a low signal level. 32 
However, all GNSS receivers may not offer the same sensitivity and robustness to this scenario.  33 
For GNSS-based PRTC output signals, one proposal is to advertise an alarm on poor signal status, but every 34 
protocol may have its own alarm mapping 35 
To cover the all the relevant functional scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.6-1 steps through the 36 
Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in order.  In this table each of the status items corresponds to the conditions 37 
defined above. 38 
 39

3.3.7 Performance test of O-DU Synchronized from either Local or Remote PRTC 2 
using ITU-T G.8275.1 PTP Profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test scope is relevant to LLS-C1 to LLS-C4. 5 
This test is CONDITIONAL-MANDATORY for O-DUs which support LLS-C1, LLS-C2 and do not only derive 6 
their timing information from an embedded PRTC.   7 
This test is OPTIONAL for O-DUs that only support LLS-C3 or LLS-C4 topology and is dependent on the 8 
availability of a measurement point.  For equipment that only supports LLS-C3 or LLS-C4, if the measurement 9 
point is not available, then the O-DU shall document that this conformance test cannot be performed. 10 
This test validates that an O-DU correctly synchronizes to incoming S-Plane timing information, from a CUSM-11 
plane Emulator which is emulating: 12 
• Either a local PRTC (using 1PPS+ serial link interface, e.g. ITU-T G.8271, see case b in figure 3.3.1-1) or 13 
local PRTC/T-GM (PTP and optionally SyncE, see case c in figure 3.3.1-1) and meeting ITU-T G.8271.1 [7] 14 
reference point B network limits. 15 
• Or a remote PRTC/T-GM (PTP and optionally SyncE, see case d in figure 3.3.1-1) meeting ITU-T G.8271.1 16 
reference point C network limits. The CUSM-E may be configured to inject either ideal or normal operating 17 
condition noise into the S-Plane timing information. Frequency and time error measured at the output of the O-18 
DU must be within specified limits, which may differ between LLS-C1-C4 configurations.  19 
As an example, the local reference link may use ITU-T G.8271 Annex A “1PPS+ToD” protocol. 20 
This test covers the two classes defined by CUS -plane spec for LLS -C1 and LLS -C2 (class A has ±15 ppb 21 
frequency error limit; class B has ±5 ppb limit).  22 
This test is defined assuming a Full Timing Support (FTS) profile used on all PTP ports of the O -DU.  Partial 23 
timing support is left for further study. 24 
The test intent is to exercise S-Plane performance under ideal and a typical/normal operating condition.  The test is 25 
not intended to exercise worst case conditions. It is the vendor’s responsibility to make sure that limits defined in 26 
the test are also met in worse-case field conditions.  Variable temperature, PTP PDV tolerance and SyncE 27 
jitter/wander tolerance, holdover and transients are beyond the scope of the CUS-Plane specification [2]. 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
Conformance Functional test 3.3.5 has successfully passed. 31 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-Plane Emulator’s time reference output interface.  32 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-E’s SMO or M-Plane function. (as defined in 3.3.1) 33 
C. Test Methodology 34 
a. Initial Conditions 35 
These tests configure the DUT (O-DU) using the CUSM-Plane emulator’s SMO or M-Plane features.  The O-36 
DU configuration depends on which LLS-C1-C4 topologies are to be tested and also it depends on whether the 37 
PRTC is local or remote.   38 
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2 configuration, the test is set up to measure frequency and time error on one of the 39 
Ethernet master fronthaul ports of the DUT. 40 
For LLS-C3 and LLS-C4 configuration, the test is configured to measure time error on a measurement port of 41 
the O-DU, typically a 1PPS signal if available or an unused Ethernet port. 42

CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 1

CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU -T 3 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value.  4 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to deliver 1PPS and act as a PRTC advertising LOCKED status over its 5 
serial link with nominal quality level (whatever protocol is used, ITU -T G.8271 or proprietary).  6 
Once the DUT has been configured, the DUT shall have achieved frequency and phase lock prior to starting 7 
the test. 8 
b. Procedure:  9 
Unlike the functional test defined in section 3.3.5 3.3.2, where start-up / nominal / degraded scenarios are 10 
tested, only nominal scenarios with ideal and normal operation input noise are tested in this section. 11 
1. Ideal Operation: The time source provides “ideal” O-DU synchronization input with no implicitly 12 
added dynamic or constant time error. This applies when testing with either a local or remote time 13 
source. 14 
2. Normal Operation: The time source provides an input stimulus with some added noise that is “within 15 
normal operating limits.” O-DU inputs as specified in CUS-Plane Specification [2]. The TEL stimulus is 16 
split between dynamic (|dTEL|) and constant (|cTE|) and is shown in Table 3.3.7-1.  The maximum time 17 
error (|TEL|) is  18 
• 1100ns at ITU-T G.8271.1 [7] section 7.3 reference point C (for remote PRTC/T-GM over PTP) . 19 
• 100ns at ITU-T G.8271.1 [7] section 7.2 reference point B (for both local PRTC/T-GM over PTP, and 20 
PRTC over 1PPS+ serial link interface) 21 
The TEL stimulus is split between dynamic (|dTEL|) and constant (|cTE|) and is shown in Table 3.3.7-1.  The 22 
time error added to the input signal shall follow a sinusoidal waveform with amplitude (A) and frequency (f) as 23 
specified in Table 3.3.7-1. Three such signal frequencies are specified for this test, but intermediate ones can 24 
be used for testing as well. 25

3.4 UC-Plane Measurements O-DU 2 
3.4.1 UC-Plane Tests 3 
This section describes conformance test scenarios for O-DU equipment implementing the U-Plane and C-Plane O-RAN 4 
option 7.2x protocols.  In these set of tests, the device under test (DUT) is either a stand -alone O-DU, or a combined O-5 
CU + O-DU from a single vendor.  Throughout this section, we may refer to the DUT generically as the O-DU for 6 
brevity, keeping in mind that there are these two potential DUT variants. 7 
3.4.2 UC-Plane Standard Test Definitions 8 
Section 2.2 outlines the test configuration for the O-DU tests in this section and provides an overview of the Test 9 
Equipment O-DU (TED) required to conduct the tests.  The following are the generic test steps to be used, although 10 
specific tests may deviate from this general procedure: 11 
1) Configure the Test Equipment, O-DU (TED) for test execution, which may include defining the specific test to 12 
execute. This includes configuring the various components comprising the TED:   13 
a. Configure the Core Emulator (and O-CU Emulator in the case of a stand-alone O-DU DUT) and the 14 
X2 signalling emulator for NSA mode such that it is ready to communicate with the DUT via the 15 
appropriate interfaces for the specific test scenario 16 
b. Configure the O-RU + UE Emulator such that it is ready to communicate to the DUT over the 17 
CUSM-planes of the open fronthaul interface for the specific test scenario, which may include 18 
configuring the O-RU emulator to emulate a certain type of O-RU, e.g. CAT-A, CAT-B, TDD, FDD; 19 
and configuring the UE emulator appropriately such that it can connect to the network for the specific 20 
test scenario      21 
2) Configure the O-DU DUT via the O1 (if available) or EMS interface to provision the DUT in order to place it 22 
into the appropriate modes to exercise the specific scenario and features under test.  Note that these should not 23 
be special test modes but are instead production modes that are used for provisioning the commercial O -DU to 24 
support various deployment configurations 25 
3) Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU emulator via the open 26 
fronthaul interface and on to the rest of the emulated network via the F1 interface  27 
4) Observe that the UE Emulator successfully attaches to the network and has successful data communications in 28 
both the downlink and uplink 29 
5) Perform detailed observation and analysis of the front haul data stream of the O -DU DUT in order to ascertain 30 
compliance to the specifications.   31 
 32 
3.4.3 Minimum Capabilities of the TED for U-Plane and C-Plane Tests 33 
Since many features of the O-RAN protocol rely on the O-DU instructing the O-RU to put data in specific resource 34 
blocks using a specific compression method it is imperative that the test equipment support features that allow detailed 35 
observation and analysis of the front haul data stream.  Furthermore, since the O-DU is meant to support various classes 36 
of O-RU with different feature sets, e.g. CAT-A or CAT-B, FR1 or FR2, different beamforming methods to multiple 37 
UEs, different compression schemes, etc.., it is important that the TED has the flexibility to effectively emulate the 38 
various scenarios in a robust and repeatable manner in order to test the various features.  As noted in Sec 2.2, this 39 
specification does not preclude the use of the commercial equivalent elements instea d of emulators, but must support a 40 
level of configurability and repeatability to ensure that the required features in the O-DU front-haul are effectively and 41 
repeatably exercised.  With use of either node emulators or commercial equivalents, the required t est outcomes and 42 
reports must be effectively and repeatably reproduced.  The rest of this section shall assume emulators are used for 43 
brevity of description.             44 
 Core + O-CU Emulator for Testing a Stand-alone O-DU DUT 45 
• Must have the capability of emulating and observing the appropriate signals at the F1 interface that enables the 46 
O-DU DUT to support connecting with the UE Emulator through the O -RU Emulator via the open front haul   47

 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Base CAT-A O-RU 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 5 
support connecting with a CAT-A O-RU with no beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.   6 
 7 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 8 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a CAT-A O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to 9 
synchronize with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles for CAT-A O-10 
RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed 11 
point IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario.   12 
 13 
C. Test Methodology 14 
1. Initial Conditions 15 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with 16 
the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator to be a CAT-A O-RU with no 17 
beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format. 18 
2. Procedure 19 
i. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU 20 
emulator  21 
ii. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  22 
iii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU 23 
Emulator including used section types and section extensions  24 
 25 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 26 
1. Non-zero data throughput in both uplink and downlink is observed 27 
2. Log of section types and section extensions successfully used  28 
 29

 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Base CAT-B O-RU 32 
A. Test Description and Applicability 33 
This test is MANDATORY. 34 
 35 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 36 
support connecting with a CAT-B O-RU with beam-index based beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.   37 
 38 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39

synchronize with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles for a CAT-B 41 
O-RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25], e.g. Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit 42 
fixed point IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario.   43 
 44 
C. Test Methodology 45 
a. Initial Conditions 46 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with 47 
the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator to be a CAT-B O-RU with beam-48

 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  4 
This section describes beamforming conformance tests for O-RAN fronthaul interface on the O-DU. The tests do not 5 
aim to test the O-DU beamforming performance or general capabilities.   The conformance tests are designed to 6 
validate that the O-DU correctly describes the Beamforming methods via C-plane messages according to the O-RAN 7 
Fronthaul interface spec. The tests are configured following the outline in the section 2.2 description of the TED.  8 
As noted earlier in section 2.2, the O-DU is assumed to be a commercial product that may support a limited set of  9 
configurations.  Therefore, these beamforming tests will present a suggested method for evaluating protocol 10 
conformance.  The tester may choose other configurations which also clearly evaluate the conformance of the O -DU to 11 
the same protocol syntax and semantics.  12 
 13 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP – Predefined-beam Beamforming 14 
 15 
A. Test Description and Applicability 16 
This test is MANDATORY. 17 
The purpose of this test is to validate the basic operation of the O-DU DUT when configured to use predefined-beams 18 
in a O-RU.  19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with an O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize to a 21 
common sync source with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR BF profiles for O-22 
RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed point 23 
IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario. 24 
 25 
The O-DU DUT must exercise at least two different beams to serve at least two SS Blocks (SSBs) and beam sweeping.  26 
The two beams under test, i.e. beam=A and beam=B, can have neither a vector size of one (i.e. only contains a single 27 
beam weight value) nor have identical beam weight values (i.e. no beamforming).   Additionally, O-DU DUT cannot 28 
assign beamId=0x0000 (i.e. no beamforming) to any of the two beams when sending beamforming information to the 29 
O-RU emulator. The O-DU might retrieve a list of O-RU beam capabilities to be able to generate beam weight vectors 30 
supported by the O-RU emulator. The O-DU DUT will use at least any two set of beam weight vectors to converge 31 
beamforming information to the O-RU emulator along with the test vectors (IQ data) containing SSB.    32 
 33 
The O-RU emulator must be configured to report support for weight-based beamforming in the M-Plane capabilities to 34 
allow the O-DU DUT to use weight-based beamforming.  It is assumed that the O-DU can be configured in some way 35 
to force the use of dynamic weight-based beamforming.   36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it carries out the use of SSBs and beam sweeping through its interfaces 40 
with the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator with weight-based beamforming 41 
and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.  42 
b. Procedure 43 
i. O-DU DUT starts broadcasting procedure and beam sweeping 44 
ii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU Emulator including 45 
used section types and section extensions 46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 47 
a. Successful decoding of SSBs 48 
b. Log of at least two different assigned beamIds (i.e. beamId=A and beamId=B) are used and none of them are 49 
beamId=0x0000 50 
c. Log of at least two different assigned beam weight vectors are used for beam=A and beam=B.  51 
 52 
 53

 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP – Weight-based Beamforming 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 5 
support connecting with a O-RU emulator with weight-based beamforming. This test exercises the beamId field found 6 
in the C-plane section descriptions as well as section extension = 1 to converge beamforming information to the O -RU 7 
emulator of TED.   8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with an O-RU for 5G New Radio and is synchronized with the O-RU 11 
emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR BF profiles for O-RU as specified in the Fronthaul 12 
Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed point IQ format), or any other suitable 13 
profile that satisfies the test scenario. 14 
 15 
The O-DU must exercise at least two different DL beams. In matrix form, the column dimension of the beam weights, 16 
as defined in Section Extension Type 1 defined in the O-RAN CUS Specification [2] clause 7.7.1., corresponds to the 17 
number of beamIds, and the row dimension to the number of TRXs of the O-RU emulator. The number of beamIds 18 
must be greater than or equal to 2. Additionally, O-DU DUT cannot assign beamId=0x0000 (i.e. no beamforming) to 19 
any of the two beams when sending beamforming information to the O-RU emulator. 20 
 21 
The O-DU might retrieve a list of O-RU beam capabilities to be able to generate beam weight vectors (i.e., columns of 22 
the beam weight matrix) supported by the O-RU emulator. The O-DU DUT will use at least two beam weight vectors to 23 
convey beamforming information to the O-RU emulator along with the test vectors (IQ data).    24 
 25 
The O-RU emulator must be configured to report support for weight-based beamforming in the M-Plane capabilities to 26 
allow the O-DU DUT to use weight-based beamforming.  It is assumed that the O-DU can be configured in some way 27 
to force the use of dynamic weight-based beamforming.   28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it carries out the broadcasting of common control channels (e.g., SSB) 32 
through its interfaces with the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator with weight-33 
based beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.  34 
b. Procedure 35 
i. O-DU DUT starts broadcasting procedure and beam sweeping 36 
ii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU Emulator including 37 
used section types and section extensions 38 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 39 
a. Successful decoding of one or more SSBs 40 
b. Log of at least two different assigned beamIds (i.e. beamId=A and beamId=B) are used and none of them are 41 
beamId=0x0000 42 
c. Log of at least two different assigned beam weight vectors are used for beam=A and beam=B.  43 
 44 
 45 
 46
